Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Syngynge he was or floytynge alle þe daye
He was as fresshe as is þe moneth of Maye
Schorte was his gowne with sleves longe ⁊and wyde
Wele couthe he sitte on an horse ande fair ride
He cowde songes make ande wele endite
Iuste ⁊and eke daunse purtreye and wryte
So hoote he louede þat by nyȝht̉er/re tale
He slepte no more þan doith a nyghtyngale
Curteyse he was louely ande seruisable
Ande kerffe be forne his fader at þe table
A yoman hadde he and seruᵃntes no moo
At þat tyme for hym lyste ryde soo .
Ande he was cladde in coote and hoode of grene
A scheefe of pococke arwes bryȝht ⁊and keene
Vnder his belte he bare full thriftely
Wel cowthe he dresse his takell yomanly
His Arwes drowȝed noȝt with feres lowe
Ande in his horde he bare a myȝhty bowe
A notte hede hadde he with a browne visage
Off wode crafte wel couthe he all þe vsage
Vp on his arme he bare a gaye bracēmre
Ande be his side a swerde and a boclere
Ande on þat other side a gaye dagere
Harneseide wele and scharpe as poynte of spere
A xpofore on his breste of siluer schene
An horne he bare þe Bawderike was of grene
A forster was he sothely as I gesse
Ther was also a nonne a Prioresse
That of hir smylynge was full sympile and coye
Hir greteste othe was but by seynt loye
Ande sche was iclepede madame englentyne
Full wele sche songe þe seruise diuine
Entuned in hire nose full semely
Ande frenssh sche spake ful faire ande fetisly
After þe scole at Stratforde at þe bowe
For frenssh of paryssh was to hire vnknowe
At meete wele y taught was sche with alle
She lete no morsell from hir lippes falle
Ne wette hire fyngris in hir sause depe
Wel couthe sche carye a morsell ande wel kepe
That no drope ne fill opon hir breste
In curtesye was she full michill hir leste
Hir ouer lippe wyped scho so clene
That in hire coppe þer was no ferthynge seene
Of grece whan sche dronken hadde hire draughte
Full semely after hire mete sche raughte
Ande sikerly scho was of grete desporte
Ande full plesaunte ande amyable of porte
Ande peyned hir to countrefete chere
Off courte and to bene estateliche of maners
Ande to bene holden digne of reuerence
But for to speken of hire consience
She was so charitable and so pytous
She wolde wepe ȝiff þat sche sawe a mous
Kaughte in a trappe if it were dede or bledde
Off smale houndes hadde sche þat sche fedde
With rostede flessh or mylke or wastell brede
But soore wepte scho if one of hem were dede
Or if men smote it with a ȝerde smerte
Ande alle was conscience ande tendir herte
Full semelich hire wympill / pynchede was
Hire noose was streiȝhte hir eyen greye as glasse
Hire mouthe full smalle ande þerto softe and rede
But sikerly scho hadde a faire forhede
It was al moste a spanne broode I trowe
For hardely scho was not vndirgrowe
Full fetyse was hire clooke as I was ware
Of smal corall a boute hire arme sche bare
A paire of bedes gawdede all with grene
Ande þer on henge a broche of golde full schene
On whiche þ̉er/re was firste writen a Crownede . A
Ande after / Amor vincit omnia .
An nother Nonne with hire hadde sche
That was hire chappelleyn ande pstes three
A Monke þ̉er/re was a faire for þe maystrye
An owte rider þat louede venerye
A manly man to bene an abbot able
Full mony a deynte horse he hadde in stable
Ande when he rode men myȝhte his bridell here
Gyngelynge in a whystlynge wynde as clere
Ande eke as lowde as doith þe chapell belle
There as þis lorde was keper of the selle
The rewle of seynt Mawre or of seynte beneite
By cause þat it was olde ande som dele streite
This ilke monke lete olde thynges pace
Ande helde after þe newe worlde þe space
He ȝaf of þe texte a pullede henne
That seith þat hunters bene noȝt holy men
Ne þat a monke whan he is rechelesse
Is likkenede till a fyssh when he is waterlesse
This is to seye A monke owte of his Cloystere
But þilke texte helde he noȝte worth an oystre
Ande I seide his opinioıı̄un was goode
What schulde he studye ande make hym selfe woode
Vp on a booke in Cloystre al weye to poure
Or swynke with his hondes ande laboure
As Austyn bitt howe schall þe worlde be ʆser/siruede
Lat Austyn haue his swynke to hym reseruede
Ther fore he was a prykasour a ryȝhte
Greyhoundes he hadde as swyfte as fowle in flyghte
Off prykkynge ande of huntynge for þe hare
Was all his luste for no coste wolde he spare
I seigh his sleves y pᵃfiled att þe honde
With grise and þat þe fyneste of a londe
Ande for to festene his hoode vndir þe chynne
He hadde of golde y wroȝhte a full curious pynne
A loue knotte in þe gretter ende þer was
His hede was ballede þat schone as eny glasse
Ande eke his face as he hadde bene anoynte
He was a lorde full fatte ande in goode poynte
His eyen were stepe ⁊and rollynge in his hede
That stemed as a fourneys of a leede
His botes souple his horse in greteastate
Nowe certanly he was a faire prelate
He nas not pale as a for pynnede goyste
A fatte swan loued he beste of any royste
His palfreye was as browne as is a berye
A frere þer was a wantoıı̄un ande a merye
A lymytour a full solempne man
In alle þe orders foure is none þat kan
So mychell of dalyaunce ande faire langage
He hadde made full monye a maryage
Of ȝonge wōmmen at his own coste
Vn to his ordre he was a noble poste
Ful wele belouede ande familiare was he
With Fraunkeleyns ouer alle in his cuntree
Ande with worthy wōmmen of the towne
For he hadde power of confessioune
As seide hym selfe more þan a curate
For in his ordre he was licenciate
Full swetely herde he confessioıı̄un
Ande plesaunte was his absolucioun
He was an esy man to ȝefe penaunce
Ther as he wyste to haue a goode pytaunce
For vnto a poure order forto ȝiffe
It is a signe þᵗat a man is wele y schryffe
For if he ȝaff he durste make a vaunte
He wyste þat a manne was repentaunte
For mony a man is so harde of his herte
He may noȝt wepe all þof hym sore a smerte
There fore in stede of wepynge and prayers
Men mote ȝiffe siluer to þe pour freres
His typete was aye farsed full of knyves
Ande pynnes for to ȝiff faire wyffes
And certenly he hadde a mery note
Wele cowth he syngen ande pleyen on a roote
Off ȝeddynges he bare witterly þe prise
His nekke was was whyte as þe floure delyse
Ther to he was stronge as a champioıı̄un
He knewe þe tauernes wele in eủer/rey towne
Ande eủer/reyche hostiler and tapister
Bette þan a lazare or a beggere
For vn to swiche a worthy man as he
Acorded noȝt as by his faculte
To haue with swiche seke lazars acquayntaıı̄unce
It is noȝt honeste it may noȝte avaunce
Forto delen with swiche poraille
But all with ryche ande with sellers of vitaille
Ande oủer/re alle þer as ꝓprofite schulde arise
Curtas he was ande lowly of seruyse
Ther nas no man nowher so vertuose
He was þe beste begger in all his house
For thogh a wydewe hadde noȝte a scho
So plesaıı̄unte was he in principio
Ȝet wolde he haf a farthynge or he wente
His purchase was wele bett̉er/re þan his rente
Ande rage he cowthe riȝht as it were a whelpe
In louedayes þer cowthe he myche helpe
For ther he was noȝt liche a Cloysterer
With a thredebare cope as a pore scolere
But he was like a maistr or a pope
Off double worstede was his semy cope
That rounded was as a bell . on þe presse
Somwhat he lispede for his wantounesse
To make his ynglyssh swete opon his tonge
And in his harpynge when þat he hadde y songe
His eyen twynklede in his hede a ryght
As done þe sterres in þe frosty nyghte
This worthy limitour was cleped huberte
A marchaunt þ̉er/re was with a forkede berde
In mot ⁊and hiegh on horse he satte
Vpon his hede a flaundressbeuer hatte
His botes clasped fair ande fetyslye
His resoıı̄uns he spake full solempnely
Shewynge al weye þe encrese of his wynnynge
He wolde þe see were kepte for eny thynge
Betwyx Midellburgh ande Orwelle
Wele cowthe he in eschaunche scheldes selle
This worthy man full wele his wytte be sette
Ther wyste no wyȝhte þat he was in dette
So estately was he of his gouernance
With his bargaynes and with his cheuysshance
For sothe he was a worthy man with alle
But sotheliche to seyne I note howe men hym calle
A Clerke þer was of Oxenforde also
That vn to logyke hadde longe y goo
As lene was his horse as is a raake
Ande he nas not right fatte I vndirtake
But loked holowe and þer to soburly
Full thredbare was his ouereste courtebye
For he hadde geten hym no benefice
Ne was so worldly to haue an office
For hym leuer haffe at his beddys hede
Twenty bookes y cladde in blakke anderede
Off Aristotill ande of philosophie
Than robes riche or fythel or gaye sawterye
But alle bi þat he was a philisopher
Ȝet hadde he but litill colde in coffr
But all þat he myȝhte of his frendes hente
On bookes ande on lernynge he it spente
Ande besily gan for þe soules preye
Of hem þat fonde hym to scole whar with aye
Off studye toke he moste cure ande hede
Nought oo worde spake he mor þan was nede
Ande þat was seide in forme ande reuerence
And schorte and quyk and full of goode sentence
Sownynge in morall vertue was his specche
Ande gladly wolde he lerne and gladlyteecche
A sergeant of þe lawe ware and wyse
That often hadde bene at paruyce
That was also full riche of excellence
Discrete he was ande of grete reuerence
He semed swiche his wordes wer so wyse
Iustise he was full often in assise
By patent and by pleyne cōmmissione
For his science ande for his heigh renowne
Off fees and robes hadde he mony one
So grete a purchasour was nowhere none
Alle was fee symple to hym in effecte
His purchasynge myȝht not bene in fecte
Nowhere so besy as he þer nas
Ande ȝet he semede besier þan he was
In termes hadde he caases and domes all
That from þe tyme of kynge Willᵃm wer falle
Ther to he cowthe endite ande make a thynge
Ther couthe no wyght pynche at his wrytynge
Ande euery statute couthe he pleyne by rote
He roode but homly in a medlede coote
Gert with a seynt of selke with barres smale
Off his aray tell I no lenger tale
A Fraunkeleyn was in his companye
White was his berde as is þe daysye
Of his complexion he was sanguyne
Wele louede he by þe morue a soppe in wyne
To lyuen in delite eủer/re was his wone
For he was Epycurues own sonne
That helde opinion þat pleyne delite
Was verrey felicite perfite
An householder ande þat a grete was he
Seynt Iulyan he was in his cuntree
His brede his ale was alweys aft̉er/re one
A bett̉er/re envyned man was nowhere noone
With oute Baken mete was neuer his house
Off fyssh ande flessh ande þat so plentevous
It sewede in his howse of mete and drynke
Offall deyntes þat men couthe thynke
After þe sondry sesoıı̄uns of þe ȝere
So chaunchede he his mete and his sopere
Full mony a fatte partriche hadde he in Mewe
And mony a breme ande eke luces in stewe
Woo was his Cooke but his sauce were
Poynant ande scharpe and redy in all his geere
His table dormant in his halle alweye
Stoode redy couerede all þe longe daye
At sessions þer was he lorde ande sire
Full ofte tyme he was knyȝhte of þe schyre
An Anelas ande a gisperal of silke
Henge at his gyrdell white as morne mylke
A scherreffe hadde he bene ande a countour
Was nowher swiche a worthy vauasour
An haburdassher ande a carpentere
A webbe a Dyere ande a tapesere
And þei were clothed alle in oo lyuereye
Off a solempne and a grete fraternite
Full fressh ande newe here eere a pyked was
Her knyffes wer chapede noȝte with brasse
But all wyth siluer wroȝhte full clene and wele
Here gerdells and her pouches eủer/reydele
Wele semed eche of hem a feir burgeyse
To sitten in a ȝelde halle on a deese
Eủer/reyche For þe wysdome þat he kanne
Was schaply for to bene an Alderman
For Catell hadde þei ynogh ande rente
And eke her wyffes wolde it wele assente
And ellis ceyteyn þei wer to blame
It is full fair to be cleped madame
And gone to vigilies all be fore
Ande haue a mantell ryallyche y boor
A Cooke þei hadde with hem for þe nonse
To boylle þe Chikens with þe marybones
And powdr marchant tarte and Galyngale
Wele cowthe he knowe a draght of londoıı̄un ale
He couthe roiste ande seeth ande broill and frye
Maken mortrewes and wele baken a pye
But grete harme was it as it thoghte me
That on his schyne a mormaylle hadde he
For blanke manger þat made he with þe beste
A schipman was þer wōmnynge fer be weste
For ought I wote he was of dertenmouthe
He roode opon a Rouncy as he couthe
In a gowne of faldynge to to kenee
A dagger hangyng in a lase hadde he
A bowten his nekke vndir his arme down
The hote somer hadde made his hewe al browne
Ande certenly he was a goode felawe
Full mony a draȝhte of wyne hadde he drawe
From Burdeux warde while þe chapmen slepe
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe
Yff þat he fauȝhte ande hadde þe hyer honde
By water he sente hem home to euery londe
But of his Crafte to rekken wele his tydes
Hys stremes and his daungers hym besydes
His herberewe ⁊and his moone ⁊and his ledmaunage
Ther nas none swiche from hulle to Cartage
Hardy he was and wyse to vndirtake
With mony a tempeste hadde his berde bene schake
He knewe alle þe hauenes as þei wer
Fro Gotlonde to þe Cape defynyster
And eủer/rey Cryke in bretaygne ande in spayne
His barge y clepede y clepede was þe Mawdeleyne
With us þer was a doctour of phisyke
In all þis worlde ne was þ̉er/re none hym like
To speke of phisyke ande of surgerye
For he was groundede in astronomye
He kepte his pacience a full grete dele
In houres by his magyk naturelle
Wele couthe he fortune þe ascendente
Off his ymage for his paciente
He knewe þe cause of eủer/reiche maladye
Were it of hoote or colde or moste or drye
And wher engendred and of what humor
He was a verrey parfite practisour
The cause I knowe and of his harme þe rote
Onon he ȝaff þe seke man his boote
Full redy hadde he his apotekaries
To sonde hem dragges and his lettuaries
For eche of hem made other for to wynne
Her frendschipe nas not newe for to gynne
Wele knowe he þe olde Escalapius
Ande discorides ande eke Rufus
Olde ypocras . haly . Ande Galien
Serapioıı̄un rasy and auyen .
Aueroys damascien / ⁊and constantyne
Bernarde ⁊and Gatisdene ⁊and Gilbertyne
Off his dyete mesurable was he
For it was of no suꝑper/parfluite
But of grete nurryshynge ande digestable
His studye was but litill on þe bible
In sangweyne ande in peres cladde he was alle
Lynede with tapheta and with sendall
And ȝet he was bot esy of despense
He kepte þat he wanne in pestilence
For golde in phisike is acordiall
Ther for he louede golde in specialle
A goode wyffe þ̉er/re was of beside bathe
But sche was somdele defe and þat was skaathe
Of clothe makynge scho hadde swiche an haunte
She passed hem of ypres ande of gaunte
In all þe parissh wyffe ne was þer none
That to þe offerynge to forne hir schulde goone
Ande if þer did certeyne wrothe was sche
That sche was oute of all charitee
Hir coủer/rechiefes full fyne wer of grounde
I dorste swer þei weyden . x pounde
That on a sonday weren vp on hir hede
Her hosen weren fyne of rede skarlete
Full streyte y tyede and schoose full softe and newe
Bolde was hir face ande fair and rede of hewe
She was a worthy wōmman all her lyue
Husbondes at þe chirche dor scho hadde fyffe
With outen oþer company in thouȝhte
But þer of nedeth it to speke riȝhte moȝhte
Ande thries hadde sche bene at Ihrlm
She hadde passed mony a stronge streme
At Rome scho hadde bene and at boloigne
In galise at seynt Iames and at Coloigne
Sho couthe myche on wandrynge be þe weye
Gat tothede was scho sothely for to seye
Vpon an ambler esily sche satte
Y wymplede wele ande on hir hede an hatte
Als brode as is a Bokeler or a targe
A fote mantell A bouten hir hippes large
Ande on hir feete a paire of spores scharpe
In felaschipe wele couthe scho laugh and karpe
Off remedies of loue sche knewe ꝑper/parchaunce
For scho cowthe . of þat arte þe olde daunce
A goode man was þer of religioıı̄un
And was a ꝑper/parsone of a towne
But riche he was of holy thoȝhte ande werke
He was also a lernede man and a clerke
That Cristes gospell trewly wolde preche
His parysshyns deuoutly wolde he tecche
Benigne he was Ande wonder diligente
And in aduersite full paciente
And swiche he was preved ofte sythes
Full lothe wer hym to cursen for his tythes
But rather wolde he ȝeffen oute of doute
Vn to his poure parisshens a boute
Off his offringes and of his substaunce
He couthe in litill thynge haf suffisaunce
Wyde was his ꝑper/parryssh ande house ferr a sundre
But he ne lafte not for rayne ne for thundre
In sekenes ner in myschiefe to visite
The ferrest in his ꝑper/parryssh both myche and lite
Vpon his fete and in his honde a staffe
This noble onsample to his schepe he ȝaffe
That ferste he wroȝht and aft̉er/rewarde þᵗat he tauȝhte
Oute of þe gospell he þo wrdes kaughte
Ande þis figur he hadde eke þerto
That if golde ruste what schall iren doo
For if a preste be foule on whome we truste
No wonder is a lewde man to ruste
Ande schame it is if a preste take kepe
A . schiten scheparde ande a clene schepe
Wele ouȝhte a preste en sample for to ȝyffe
By his clennesse howe þat his schepe schulde lyffe
He sette noȝte his benefice to hyre
Ande lete his schepe to ben acombred in þe myre
And ranne to londoıı̄un vn to seynt Poules
To seeke hym a Chauntr for soules
Or with a bretherede to bene with holde
But dwelled at home and kepte his folde
So þat þe wolff ne made it not myscarye
He was a scheparde ande not a Mercenarye
And þof he were holy ande vertuose
He was nouȝt to synfull men despitous
Ne of speche daungerous ne digne
But in his techynge discrete ande benigne
To drawen folke to heuen by fairnesse
By goode ensample þis was his besynesse
But it were eny ꝑper/parsoıı̄un obstinate
What so he were of hiegh or lowe astate
Hym wolde he snybbe scharply for þe nones
A bett̉er/re preste I trowe þat nowher none is
He wayted aft̉er/re no pompe ne reuerence
Ne maked hym a spicede conscience
But Cristes lore and his Apostells twelfe
He tauȝte but firste he folowed hem in hym selfe
With hym þ̉er/re was a plogh man þat was his brother
That hadde y ladde of donge full mony a fother
And a trewe swynker ande a goode was he
Lyffynge in peese ande ꝑper/parfite charite
Godde loued he beste with all his herte
At alle tymes þogh he gamed or smerte
And þan his neiȝhbore riȝht as hym selfe
He wolde thresshe and þ̉er/re to dyke ande delue
For Cristes sake for eủer/rey pore wyȝhte
With oute hir if it lay in his myghte
His tythes paied he full fair ande wele
Bothen of his ꝓpropre swynke and his Catell
In a tabbarde he roode opon a mere
Ther was also A Reve and A Mellere
A sompnoure and A pardoner also
A Maunciple and my selfe þer . war no moo
The Meller was a stoute Carle for þe nones
Full byg he was of brawne ande eke of bones
That proued wele For oủer/re alle þ̉er/re he cam
At wrastelynge he wolde ber a weye þe Ram
He was schorte schuldered a thykke knarre
Ther nas no dore þat he ne wolde heue of harre
Or breke it at a rennynge with his hede
His berde as eny sowe or fox was rede
Ande þerto brode as þof it wer a spade
Vpon þe coppe riȝht of his noose he hadde
A werte and þ̉er/re on stoode a tufte of heeres
Reede as þe birstelles of a sowes eres
His noose thrilles blakke wer ande wyde
A swerde ande Bokeler bare he be his syde
His mouthe als grete was as a grete fourneyse
He was a Iangler ande a goliardeys
And þat was moste of synne and of harlotries
Wele couthe he stelen corne and toll it thries
And ȝit he hadde a thombe of golde parde
A white Cote and a blewe hode wered he
A baggepipe wele couthe he blowe and sowne
And þ̉er/re with all he broȝht us oute of towne
A gentill manciple was þ̉er/re of a temple
Of whiche acatours myght take en semple
For to bene wyse in byynge of vitaill
For wheder þat he paied or toke be tayll
Algate he waytede so in his achate
That he was ay be forne ande in goode estate
Nowe is not þat of godde a full fair grace
That swiche a lewede māmnys wytte schall passe
The wysdom of an hepe of lerned men
Of maystres hadde he mo than thries ten
That wer of lawe exꝑper/parte ande curiouse
Of whiche þ̉er/re was a dosseyn in þat house
Worthy to bene Stewardes of Rente and londe
Off ony lorde þat is in Englelonde
To make hym lyffe by his ꝓpropre goode
In honour detteles / but if þᵗat he wer wode
Or liff als skarsly als hym liste desire
Ande able for to helpen all a schir
In eny Caase þat myȝhte falle or happe
And ȝet þis manciple sate her allder cappe
The Reue was a sklender colerike man
His berde was schauen as nyeȝh as eủer/re he can
His heer was by his eres full rownde y schorne
His toppe was dokked like a preste be forne
Full longe wer his legges and full lene
Y lyke a staffe þ̉er/re was no Calfe y seene
Wele couthe he kepe a garner or a bynne
Ther was non auditour couthe on hym wynne
Wele wyste he by þe droghte ande by þe Reyne
The ȝeldynge of his seede and of his greyne
His lordes schepe his nete his dayrye
His swyne his horse his store and his pulterye
Was holy in þis Reues gouernynge
Ande by his couenᵃnt ȝaff þe rekkenynge
Syn þat his lorde was xx ȝer of age
Ther couthe no man brynge hym in arrerage
Ther nas Baillyff ner herde ner oþ̉er/re hyne
That he ne knewe his sleght ande his covyne
Thei wer a dredde of hym as of þe deeth
His wonnynge was full fair opon an heeth
With grene treese y schadewede was his plase
He couthe bett̉er/re þan his lorde purchase
Full riche he was astored priuely
His lorde he couthe wele plesen sotelly
To yiue ⁊and lene hym of his owne goode
And haf a thanke and ȝet a cote ⁊and an hoode
In thoughte he hadde lernede a goode mister
He was a wel goode wryght a Carpenter
This Reue satte opon a full goode stotte
That was all pomely grey and hye scotte
A longe surcote of Peeres vpon he hadde
Ande by his side he bar a Rusty bladde
Off Northfolke was þis Reve of whiche I telle
Besiden a towne men clepen it Baldeswelle
Tukked he was as is a frere a boute
Ande eủer/re herode þe hyndereste of our Route
A somnour was þer with us in þat plase
That hadde a fyri cherubynnes face
For sausefleme he was with eyen narowe
Als hote he was and leccherouse as a sparowe
With scalled browes blak and piled berde
Off his visage Children weren a ferde
Ther nas quykke silủer/re litarge or brennestone
Boras orsur ne oylle of tartr noone
Ne oynement þat wolde clense and bite
That hym myȝhte helpe of his whelkes whyte
Nor of þe knobbes syttynge in his chekes
Wele loued he garleke oynyons ande eke leekꝭes
And for to drynke stronge wyne reede as blode
Than wolde he speke and crye as he wer woode
And whan þat he wel dronken hadde þe wyne
That wolde he speke no worde but latyne
A fewe termes hadde he two orthr
That he hadde lernede oute of som decree
No wonder is he harde it al þe daye
Ande eke ȝe knowen it wele howe þat a Iaye
Kan clepe watte as wele as I can þe pope
But who so couthe in other thynge hym grope
Than hadde he spente all his philosophie
Ay questio quid iuris wolde he crye .
He was a gentill harlotte ande a kynde
A better felowe schulde men not fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyne
A goode felowe to haue his concubyne
A twelfe moneth ande excuse hym at þe full
Full pⁱriuely eke a fynche couthe he pulle
Ande if he fonde owher a goode felawe
He wolde techen hym to haue none awe
In swiche caas of þe arsdekyns curs
But if mannes soule wer in his purs
For in his purse he schulde punysshede be
Purse is þe arsdekenes helle seide he
But wele I wote he liede riȝhte in dede
Off cursynge ought eche gilty man hym drede
For curs will slee / riȝht as assoilynge sauith
And also war hym of a . significauit
In daunger hadde he at his owne gyse
The ȝonge gyrles of þe diocise
Ande knewe hir counsell and what was al hir reede
A garlande hadde he sate opon his heede
Als grete as it wer for an ale stake
A bokeler hadde he made hy of a kake
With hym þ̉er/re rode a gentill pardoner
Off Rouncyvale his frende and his comper
That streiȝht was cōmmen fro þe courte of rome
Full lowde he songe come hider loue to me
This somnour bar to hym a styff burdoıı̄un
Was neủer/re trompe of halfe so grete a sown
This ꝑper/pardoner hadde heer as ȝelowe as wexe
But smothe it henge as doith a strike of flexe
By ounces henge his lokkes þat he hadde
And þ̉er/re with he his schuldernes ouer spradde
But thynne it lay by culpons one and one
But hoode for Iolitee werede he noone
For it was trussed up in his walette
Hym thouȝhte he roode al of þe newe gette
Discheuele saf his cappe he rode all bare
Swiche glarynge eyen hadde he as an hare
A vernykle hadde he sewed opon his cappe
His walet beforne hym was in his lappe
Bret full of ꝑper/pardone come fro rome all hote
A voys he hadde als small as a goote
No berde ne hadde he ne neủer/re schulde haue
Als smothe it was as it wer late y schaue
I trowe he wer a geldynge or a mare
But of his Crafte fro Berwyke in to ware
Ne was þ̉er/re swiche a nother ꝑper/pardonere
For in his male he hadde a pyleweber
Whiche þat he saide was oure lady vaille
He seide he hadde a gobette of þe seylle
That seynt Petir hadde when þat he wente
Vp on þe see till Ihu Criste hym sente
He hadde a Croyse of latoıı̄un full of stones
Ande in a glasse he hadde pikges bones
But with þise relikes when þat he fonde
A poure ꝑper/parsone dwellyng opon londe
O pon a day he gat hym more monye
Than þe ꝑper/parsonne gat in monethis tweye
And þus with feyned flat̉er/reynge and with Iapes
He made þe ꝑper/parsone and þe peple his apes
But trewly to tellen at þe laste
He was in chirche a noble ecciaste
Wele couthe he rede a lessoıı̄un or a storye
But alderbeste he songe an offertorye
For wele he wyste whan þat songe was songen
He moste preche ande wele a fyle his tonge
To wynnen siluer as he wele couthe
Ther fore he sange so merely ande lowde
Nowe haf I tolde ȝowe sothely in a clause
The astate þe araye þe noumbr ande eke þe cause
Why þat assembled was þis companye
In Suthwerke at þis gentill hostelerye
That hiȝht þe tabbarde faste by þe belle
But nowe is tyme to ȝowe for to telle
Howe þat we beren us þat ilke nyȝht
Whan we wer in þat Osterye a liȝhte
Ande after woll I tellen of our viage
And alle remenaunte of oure pilgrimage
But ferste I preye ȝowe of ȝoure Curtesye
That ȝe ne rette it noȝte my vilaynye
Thof þat I pleynly speke in þis matere
To tellen ȝowe her wordes and her cher
Ne thogh I speke her wordes ꝓpropurlye
For þis ȝe knowen als wele as I .
Who so schall tellen a tale after a man
He mote reherce als neigh as eủer/re he can
Eủer/reyche a worde if it be in his charge
All speke he neủer/re so rudely ande large
Or ells he mot telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thynges or fynde wordes newe
He may nouȝt spare all þof he wer his brother
He mot als wele seye oo . worde as a nother
Criste spake hym selfe full brode in holy writte
And wele ȝe wote no vilanye is it
Eke plato seith who so can hym reede
The wordes mote bene Cosyn to þe dede
Also I pray ȝowe forȝiff it me
All haf I not sette folke in hir degree
Here in þis tale as þat þei schulden stonde
My wytte is schorte ȝe may wele vndirstonde
Grete chere made oure oste us eủer/reichon
And to þe soper sette he us onon
He ʆser/sirued us with vitailles at þe beste
Stronge was þe wyne ande wele drynke us leste
A semely man oure oste was with alle
For to bene a Merschall in an halle
A large man he was with eyen stepe
A fairer burgese is none in chepe
Bolde of his speche ande wise and wele y tauȝhte
Ande of manhode hym lakkede riȝht nauȝhte
Eke þ̉er/reto he was riȝht a mery manne
Ande aft̉er/re soper pleien he began
Ande spake of mirthe amonge oþer thynges
Whan þat we hadde made our rekkenynges
And seide þus Nowe lordynges trewly
Ȝe beene to me welcome riȝht hertely
For be my trouthe if þat I schall not lye
I seye noȝte þis ȝere so mery a companye
At ones in þis herberowe as is nowe
Fayne wolde I done ȝowe mirthe wiste I howe
And of a myrthe I am ryght nowe be thōmghte
To done ȝowe ese Ande it schall coste noȝte
Ȝe gone to Caunturbury godde ȝowe spede
The Blesfull martir quite ȝowe ȝoure mede
Ande wele I wote as ȝe gone by þe waye
Ȝe schapen ȝowe to talen and to pleye
For trewly comforte ne mirthe is þ̉er/re none
To riden by þe weye dombe as a stoone
Ande þer for woll I maken ȝowe desporte
As I seide arste ande done ȝowe som 9forte
Ande if ȝowe liketh alle by one assente
For to stonden at my Iuggemente
Ande for to werken as I schall . ȝewe seye .
To morowen when we riden by þe weye
Nowe be my fader soule þat is dede
But ȝe be mery I will ȝiff ȝowe my hede
Holde up ȝour hondes with oute more speche
Our counseall was not longe for to seeche
Vs thought it was not worth to make to wyse
And grauntede hym withoute more avise
And badde hym seye his verdeyte as hym lyste
Lordynges qd he nowe herkeneth for þe beste
But take it noȝte I preye ȝowe in disdeigne
This is þe poynte to speke schorte ande pleyne
That eche of ȝowe to schorte with oþer weye
In þis viage schall tellen tales tweye
To Cauntirbury warde I mene it . soo
And homwardes he schall tellen other two
Off auentures þat whilom hauen befalle
Ande whiche of ȝowe þat berith hym beste of all
That is to seyne þat tellith in þis case
Tales of beste sentence Ande moste solace
Shall haue a soper at our aller cooste
Her in þis place sittynge by þis poste
Whan þat comyn a gayn from caunterbery
And for to make ȝowe þe mor merye
I will my selfe goodly with ȝowe ride
Riȝht at myn own coste and be ȝour gyde
And who so will my Iuggement withsaye
Shall paye all þat we spende by þe weye
And if ȝe wouchesaue þat it be soo
Tell me onon with outen wordes moo
Ande I woll arly schape me þer fore
This thynge was gᵃunted and our othes y swore
With full gladde herte and preiden hym alsoo
That he wolde wouchesaue for to don soo
And þat he wolde be oure gouernour
And of our tales Iugge ande repirtour
And sette a soper at a certeyn prise
And we willen rewlede bene at his deuyse
In heigh ande lowe and þus by one assente
We bene acorded to þat Iuggemente
And þer opon þe wyne was fette onone
We dronken ande to reste wente eủer/reychone
With outen eny lenger taryynge
A morowe whan þe daye gan to sprynge
Vp rose our ooste ande was our alder Cokke
Ande gadered us to gider in a flokke
And forthe we ridden a litill mor þn paase
Vn to þe waterynge of seynte thomas
Ande þere our oste gan his horse areste
And seide lordes herkeneth if ȝowe leste
Ye wote ȝe forwarde and I it ȝow recorde
Yff euensonge and morowen songe acorde
Lat se nowe ho schall . tell þe firste tale
As euer motte I drynke wyne or ale
Who so be rebell to my . Iuggemente
Shall paye for all þat by þe weye is spente
Nowe draweth or þat we ferþer wynne
Whiche þat hath þe schorteste schall begynne
Sir knyght qd he my maister and my lorde
Nowe draweth cutte for þat is myne accorde
Cometh nere qd he my lady prioresse
And ȝe sir Clerke lat be ȝour schamefastnesse
Ne studieth not lere honde to euery manne
A noon to drawe eủer/rey wighte beganne
And schortly for to tellen as it was
Wer it by auentur or sorte or caase
The south is þis þe cutte felle to þe knyȝhte
Of whiche full gladde and blithe was eủer/rey wyȝhte
And tellen he moste his tale as it was resoune
By forwarde ande by composicioıı̄un
As ȝe han herde what nedeth wordes moo
And whan þis goode man sawgh þat it was soo
As he þat wise was ande obediente
To kepen his forwarde by his free assente
He seide sethen I schall begynne þe game
What welcome be þe cutte of goddis name
Nowe lat us ride ande herkenyth what I seye
And with þat worde . we riden forthe our weye
Ande beganne with riȝht a mery cheer
His taale onon and seide as ȝe may her
Iam que domos patrias seiate post aspera gentis prelia laurigero

l.hi: ¶ Here endith þe prologe of þis booke

div.l: (base) Here bigynneth / the knyghtes tale
(base) c incipit fabula Militis ;
(base) Iamque domos patria Scithice post asꝑper/para gentis laurigero etc Here bigynneth the knygtis tale
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
(base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng

(base) This is to seyn / that wheither he or thou
(base) May with his hundred / as I spak of now
(base) Sleen his contrarie / or out of lystes dryue
(base) Thanne shal I yeue / Emelye to wyue
(base) To whom that Fortune / yeueth so fair a grace
(base) The lystes / shal I maken in this place
(base) And god so wisly / on my soule rewe
(base) As I shal / euene Iuge been and trewe
(base) Ye shul noon oother ende / with me maken
(base) That oon of yow / ne shal be deed / or taken
(base) And if yow thynketh / this is wel ysayd
(base) Sey youre auys / and holdeth yow apayd
(base) This is youre ende / and youre conclusioun
(base) ¶ Who looketh lightly now / but Palamoun
(base) Who spryngeth vp for ioye / but Arcite
(base) Who koude telle / or who koude it endite
(base) The ioye / that is maked in the place
(base) Whan Theseus / hath doon so fair a grace
(base) But doun on knees / wente euery maner wight
(base) And thonken hym / with al hir herte and myght
(base) And namely the Thebans ofte sythe
(base) And thus with good hope / and herte blythe
(base) They take hir leeue / and homward gonne they ryde
(base) To Thebes / with olde walles wyde
(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars
(base) ¶ Incipit pars secunda
(base) The ordinaunce of lystys that Thesyus ordeynyd ⁊and cᵒ
(base) I trowe / men wolde deme it necligence
(base) If I foryete / to tellen the despence
(base) Of Theseus / that gooth so bisily
(base) To maken vp the lystes / roially
(base) That swich a noble Theatre / as it was
(base) I dar wel seyn / in this world ther nas
(base) The circuit a myle was aboute
(base) Walled of stoon / and dyched al withoute
(base) Round was the shap / in manere of compas
(base) Ful of degrees / the heighte of sixty paas
(base) That whan a man / was set on o degree
(base) He letted noght his felawe for to see
(base) ¶ Estward ther stood a gate / of Marbul whit
(base) Westward / right swich another / in the oposit
(base) And shortly to concluden / swich a place
(base) Was noon in erthe / as in so lite a space
(base) For in the lond / ther was no crafty man
(base) That Geometrye / or Ars metrik kan
(base) Ne purtreyour / ne keruere of ymages
(base) That Theseus / ne yaf mete and wages

div.l: (base) The Theatre / for to maken and deuyse
(base) And for to doon / his ryte and sacrifise
(base) He Estward hath / vpon the gate aboue
(base) In worship of venus / goddesse of loue
(base) Doon maad an Auter / and an oratorie
(base) And on the westward / in memorie
(base) Of Mars / he maked hath right swich another
(base) That coste largely / of gold a fother
(base) And Northward / in a touret on the wal
(base) Of Alabastre whit and reed Coral
(base) An oratorie / riche for to see
(base) In worship / of Diane of chastitee
(base) Hath Theseus / doon wroght in noble wise
(base) ¶ But yet hadde I forgeten / to deuyse
(base) The noble keruyng and the purtreitures
(base) The shap / the contenance / and the figures
(base) That weren / in thise oratories thre
(base) ¶ First / in the temple of Venus / mayst thow se
(base) Wroght on the wal / ful pitous to biholde
(base) The broken slepes / and the sykes colde
(base) The sacred teerys / and the waymentynge
(base) The firy strokes / of the desirynge
(base) That loues seruantz / in this lyf enduren
(base) The othes / that hir couenantz assuren
(base) Plesance / and hope / desir / foolhardynesse
(base) Beautee and youthe / baudrye / richesse
(base) Charmes and force / lesynges / flaterye
(base) Despense / bisynesse / and Ialousye
(base) That wered / of yelowe gooldes a gerland
(base) And a Cokkow / sittyng on hir hand
(base) Festes / Instrumentz / caroles / daunces
(base) Lust and array / and alle the circumstaunces
(base) Of loue / whiche that I rekned / and rekne shal
(base) By ordre / weren peynted on the wal
(base) And mo / than I kan make of mencioun
(base) For soothly / al the Mount of Citheroun
(base) Ther Venus / hath hir principal dwellynge
(base) Was shewed on the wal / in purtreyynge
(base) With al the gardyn / and the lustynesse
(base) Nat was foryeten / the porter ydelnesse
(base) Ne Narcisus the faire / of yoore agon
(base) Ne yet the folie / of kyng Salomon
(base) The enchauntement of medea and hardynesse
(base) Of Iason I wil not now expresse
(base) Ne yet the grete strengthe of Ercules
(base) The enchantementz / of Medea and Circes
(base) Ne of Turnus / with the hardy fiers corage
(base) The ryche Cresus / caytif in seruage
(base) ¶ Thus may ye seen / that wisdom ne richesse
(base) Beautee / ne sleighte / strengthe hardynesse
(base) Ne may with venus / maken champartie
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For as hir lust the world than may she gye
(base) Lo al this folk so caught were in hir laas
(base) Til they for wo / ful ofte seyde allas
(base) Suffiseth heere ensamples / oon or two
(base) And though / I koude rekne a thousand mo
(base) ¶ The statue of Venus / glorious for to see
(base) Was naked / fletyng in the large See
(base) And fro the nauele doun / al couered was
(base) With wawes grene / and brighte as any glas
(base) A Citole in hir right hand / hadde she
(base) And on hir heed / ful semely for to se
(base) A rose gerland / fressh / and wel smellynge
(base) Aboue hir heed / hir dowues flikerynge
(base) Biforn hire stood / hir sone Cupido
(base) Vpon his shuldres / wynges hadde he two
(base) And blynd he was / as it is ofte seen
(base) A bowe he bar / and Arwes brighte and keene
(base) ¶ Why sholde I nat as wel / eek telle yow al
(base) The purtreyture / that was vpon the wal
(base) With Inne the temple / of myghty Mars the rede
(base) Al peynted was the wal / in lengthe and brede
(base) Lyk to the eestres / of the grisly place
(base) That highte the grete temple / of Mars in Trace
(base) In thilke colde / frosty Regioun
(base) Ther as Mars / hath his souereyn mansioun
(base) ¶ First on the wal / was peynted a Forest
(base) In which ther dwelleth / neither man ne best
(base) With knotty / knarry / bareyne trees olde
(base) Of stubbes sharpe / and hidouse to biholde
(base) In which / ther ran a rombul / in a swough
(base) As thogh a storm / sholde bresten euery bough
(base) And downward on an hil / vnder a bente
(base) Ther stood the temple / of Mars Armypotente
(base) Wroght al of burned steel / of which the entree
(base) Was long and streyt and gastly for to see
(base) And ther out cam a rage / and swich a veze
(base) That it made / al the gate for to rese
(base) The Northren light in at the dores shoon
(base) For wyndow on the wal / ne was ther noon
(base) Thurgh which men myghten / any light discerne
(base) The dore was al / of Athamant eterne
(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /
(base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong
(base) Euery piler / the temple to sustene
(base) Was tonne greet of Iren bright and shene
(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Of felonye / and al the compassynge
(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede
(base) The pike purs / and eek the pale drede
(base) The smylere / with the knyf vnder the cloke
(base) The shipne brennyng with the blake smoke
(base) The tresoun / of the mordryng in the bed
(base) The open werre / with woundes al bibled
(base) Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
(base) Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place
(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther
(base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right
(base) Amyddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
(base) With disconfort and sory contenaunce
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage
(base) Armed compleynt out hees / and fiers outrage
(base) The caroyne in the bussh / with throte ycorue
(base) A thousand slayn / and noght of qualm ystorue
(base) The tiraunt with the praye / by force yraft
(base) The town destroyed / ther was no thyng laft
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres
(base) The hunte strangled / with the wilde beres
(base) The hunt strangled with wilde bores corage
(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel
(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus
(base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet
(base) With eyen rede / and of a man he eet
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown
(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
(base) Wel koude he peynte lyfly / that it wroghte
(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye
(base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name
(base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
(base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
(base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon
(base) His sacrifice he dide / and that anon
(base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances
(base) Al telle I nat as now / his obseruances
(base) But at the laste / the Statue of Venus shook
(base) And made a signe / wher by that he took
(base) That his prayere / accepted was that day
(base) For thogh the signe / shewed a delay
(base) Yet wiste he wel / that graunted was his boone
(base) And with glad herte / he wente hym hoom ful soone
(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon
(base) Bigan / to Venus temple / for to gon
(base) Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye
(base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde
(base) Ful redily with hem / the fyr they hadde
(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al
(base) That to the sacrifice / longen shal
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse
(base) Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise
(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge

But / ar þat he had made all þis araye
He sente his knave and eke his wenche also
Vp on his nede to lond for to goo
And on þe monday when it drewe to nyȝhte
He schete his dor with oute Candell liȝhte
And dressed al thynge as it scholde be
And schortly þei clomben up al thr
Thei satten stille wel a furlonge weye
Nowe pr nr Clum saide Nicolaye
And Clum ꝙquod Iohn and clum ꝙquod alisoun
This carpent̉er/re seide his deuocioıı̄un
And stille he sitte and biddeth his praier
Awaytyng on þe reyne if he it her
The dethde slepe for wery besynesse
Fill on þis Carpent̉er/re riȝht as I gesse
A bowte Curfewe tyme or litill / mor
For trauaille of his goiste he groneth soor
And efte he routeth for his hede mys leye
Down of þe ladder stalketh nycolay
And Alisoıı̄un full softe a down she spedde
With outen wordes moo þei gone to bedde
Ther as þe Carpent̉er/re was wonte to lye
Ther was þe reuell and þe melodye
And þus lieth Alisoıı̄un and Nicolas
In besynes of merthe and of solace
Till þat þe bell of lawdes gan to rynge
And freres in þe Chauncelle goon synge
This parissh Clerke þis amorous Absoloıı̄un
Þat is for loue al wey so wo be goıı̄un
Vpo þe monday was at Osnay
With companye hym to disporte and pleye
And axed opoıı̄un caas a Cloisterer
Ful pⁱriuely aft̉er/re Iohn þe Carpenter
And he drowh hym a parte oute of þe chirche
I not I sawgh hym her not wyrche
Seth satirday I trowe þat he be wente
For tymber þ̉er/re our Abbot hath hym sente
For he is wonte for tymber for to goo
Ande dwellen at þe graunge a daye or twoo ¶
Or ells he is at his house c̉er/reteyn
Wher þat he be I can not sothely seyn
This Absaloıı̄un full Ioly was and liȝhte
And thouȝht nowe is tyme to wake alnyȝhte
For sikerly I sawe hym noȝt stirrynge
A bowten his dor sen day be gan to sprynge
So mot I thryue I schall at þe Cokkes crowe
Full pⁱriuely knokken at his wyndowe
That stant full lowe opoıı̄un his bowrs walle
To alisoıı̄un nowe will I tellen alle
My loue longynge for ȝit I schall not mysse
Þat at þe leste weye I schall her kysse
Som man comforte schall I haf ꝑper/parfaye
My mouthe hath icched al þis longe daye
Þat is a signe of kyssynge at þe leeste
All nyȝht I mette eke I was at a feste
Ther for I woll go slepe an our or tweye
And al þe nyȝht þan will I wake and playe
When þat þe firste Cokke hath crowe onon
Vp riste þis Ioly louer Absoloıı̄un
And hym araieth gaye ande poynt deuyse
But ferste he cheweth grayne and likorise
To smellen swote or he hadde kempte his her
Vndir his tonge a trewe loue he ber
For þer by wende he to be gracious
He rowmeth to þe Carpenters house
And still he stante vndir þe schotwyndowe
Vn to his breste it rauȝht it was so lowe
And softe he coughed with a semy sown
What doith ye honycombe swete Alisoun
My fair bridde my swete synamōmme
A waketh lēmman myn and spekith to me
Wel litell thenken ye vp on my woo /
That for your loue I swete as / I goo
No wonder is þough þat I swelte and swete
I morne as dothe þe lambe aft̉er/re þe tete
I wys lēmman I haue swiche loue longynge
That elke a turtell trewe is mornyng
I may not eten namor þan a mayde
Go fro þe wyndowe Iakke foole sche seide
As helpe me god it will not be compame
I loue another and ells I wer to blame
Wel bette þan þe by Ihıı̄un Absoloıı̄un
Go forth þi weye or I will or I will caste a stoon
Ande lete me slepe a xx . deuell weiye
Allas qd Absoloıı̄un and walow way
That trewe loue was eủer/re so yuell by sette
Than kisse me sen itmay be no bette ¶
For Ihıı̄un loue and for þe loue of me
Woltest þou þan go þi wey þ̉er/re with qd sche
Ȝa c̉er/retis lēmman qd þis Absoloıı̄un
Than make þe redy qd sche I come onoıı̄un
This absolon sette hym downe on his knees
And saide I am a lorde atte alle degrees
For aft̉er/re þis I hope þer comyth moore
Lēmman þi grace and swete bridde þin ore
The wyndowe sche vndoth and þat in haste
Haf do qd sche come of and spede þe faste
Lest þat our neiȝhbores þe aspie
This Absoloıı̄un gan wipe his mouthe full drye
Derke was þe nyȝht as pycche or as þe coole
And at þe wyndowe oute sche putte hir hole
And Absolon hym fell no better weres
But with his mouthe he kissed hir naked ers
Full sauourly or he was war of þis
A bak he stirte and thoȝht it was a mys
For wele he wiste a woman had no berde
He felte a thynge al rough and longe y hered
And seide fye . Allas what haue I doo .
Tehe qd sche and clapped þe wyndowe too
And absoloıı̄un goith forth a sory pase
A berde a berde seyde hende Nicolas
By goddꝭes corpus þis goith fair and wele
This sely Absoloıı̄un herde it euy dele
And on his lippe he gan for angir bite
And to hym selfe he seide I schall þe quyte
Who rubbeth nowe who froteth nowe his lippes
With duste with sonde with strawe with cloth with chippes
But Absolon þat seith full ofte allas
My soule betake I to sathanas
But me wer leủer/re þan al þis towne qd he
Of þis despite a wroken for to be
Allas qd he allas þat I ne had y blente
His hote loue is colde and al y queynte
For fro þat tyme þat he had kyssed her erse
Of ꝑper/paramours he sette not a kers
For he was heled of his maladye
Full ofte ꝑper/paramours he gan defye
And weped as doith a childe þat is y bete
A softe paas he wente ouer þe strete
Vn till a smyth men clepen dawn garueys
That in his forge smythieth plugh harneys
He scharpeth schare and cultur besily
This absoloıı̄un knokketh all esely ¶
And seyde vn to garueys and þat a noon
What who arte þou it am I Absoloıı̄un
What Absolon what Cristis swete tree
Why rise ȝe so rathe benedicite
What erly ȝowe som gay gerle god it wote
Hath brouȝt ȝowe þus on þe virtotte
Be seynte note ȝe wote wele what I mene
This absolon ne rought not a bene
Off all his pleye no worde a ȝeyn he ȝaff
He hadde mor towe on his distaffe
Than garueys knewe ande seide frende so dere
The hote culter in þe chymyney her
As lene it me I haf þer with to done
I woll brynge it a gayn full sone
Garueys answerde certis wer it golde
Or in a pole nobles al vntolde
Thowe schuldest haf as I am trewe smyth
Ey Cristes foo what will ȝe do þ̉er/re with
Therof qd Absolon be as be may
I schall wele tell it þe to morwe daye
And cauȝht þe cultr be þe colde stele
Ful softe oute at þe dor he gan stele
And wente vn to þe Carpent̉er/re walle
He koghed firste and knokked þ̉er/rewith all
Vpon þe wyndowe riȝht as he did er
This Alison answered who is þer
That knokketh so I warant it a thefe
Wy nay qd he god wite my swete lefe
I am þin Absoloıı̄un þi der derlynge
Of gold qd he I haf þe broȝht a rynge
My moder ȝaff it me so god me saue
Full fyne it is and þer to wele y graue
This will I ȝiffen þe if þou me kysse
This Nicolas was risen for to pisse
And thouȝht he wolde amenden al þe iape
He schuld kisse his ers er he did skape
And up þe wyndowe did he hastily
And oute his ers he putte priuely
Ouer þe bottoke to þe haunche bone
And þerwith spake þis clerke þis Absoloıı̄un
Speke swete bridde I note wher þou arte
This nycholas onoıı̄un let flye a farte
Als grete as it had bene a thunder dent
That with þe stroke he was almoste y blente
And he was redy with his iren hote
And nicholas in þe ers he smote ¶
Off goth þe skynne an handbrede a boute
The hote cultr brenned so his toute
And for þe smerte he wenyd for to dye
As he wer wode for woo he gan to crye
Help water water helpe for goddis herte
This Carpent̉er/re oute of his slomber sterte
And harde one crien water as he wer wode
And thouȝht allas Noyes flode
And sette hym with wordes moo
And with an ax he smote þe corde a twoo
And down goith all he fonde neither to selle
Brede nether ale till he come to þe sell
Opon þe floor ande þer in swown he laye
Vp stirte hir Alison and Nicolay
And criede oute and and harrowe in þe strete
The neȝhbores both smale and grete
In runnen for to gawren on þis man
That a swowen lay both pale and wanne
For with þat fall he hath y brusten his arme
But stonden he moste vn to his own harme
For whan he spake he was onon borne down
With hende Nicolas and Alisoun
Thei tolde eủer/rey man þat he was wode
He was so a gaste of þe Noyes flode
Thurgh fantasie þat of his vanite
He hadde y bouȝht hym knedynge tubbes thr
And had hem hanged in þe roofe a bouen
And þat he praied hym for goddis louen
To sitten in þe roofe pur companye
The folk gan laghen at his fantasye
And to þe roofe þei kokyn and þei gape
And turned all his harme vn to a Iape
For what so þis Carpenter answerde
It was for noȝht no man his resoıı̄un herde
With othes grete he was so sworne a down
That he was holden wode in al þat town
For eủer/rey clerk onon riȝht helde with other
Thei seide þe man is wode my lefe brother
And eủer/rey wiȝht gan laghen at his stryfe
Thus swyved was þe Carpenters wyffe
For all his kepyng and his Ialowsie
And Absolon hath kyssed her nethereye
And Nicolas is skalded in his toute
Þis tale is done and god saue all þe route

div.l: (base) ¶ The Prologe / of the Reues tale
(base) Whan folk hadde laughen / at this nyce cas
(base) Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas
(base) Diuerse folk / diuersely they seyde
(base) But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
(base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
(base) But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
(base) By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
(base) A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
(base) He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
(base) So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
(base) With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age
(base) Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
(base) Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
(base) But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
(base) That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
(base) Til it be roten / in Mollok or in stree
(base) We olde men / I drede so fare we
(base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe
(base) For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
(base) As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
(base) Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke
(base) Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
(base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
(base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
(base) For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
(base) Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon
(base) And euere sith / hath so the tappe yronne
(base) Til that almoost / al empty is the tonne
(base) The streem of lyf / now droppeth on the chymbe
(base) The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
(base) Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yoore
(base) With olde folk / saue dotage is namoore
(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng
(base) He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng

div.l: (base) He seyde / what amounteth al this wit
(base) What shal we speke alday / of holy writ
(base) The deuel made / a Reue for to preche
(base) Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche
(base) Sey forth thy tale / and tarie noght the tyme
(base) Lo Depeford / and it is half wey pryme
(base) Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
(base) It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
(base) ¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue
(base) I pray yow alle / that ye noght yow greue
(base) Thogh I answere / and som del sette his howue
(base) For leueful is / with force / force of showue
(base) This dronken Millere / hath ytoold vs heer
(base) How that / bigiled was a Carpenter
(base) Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon
(base) And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anon
(base) Right / in his cherles termes / wol I speke
(base) I pray to god / his nekke mote to breke
(base) He kan wel / in myn eye / seen a stalke
(base) But in his owene / he kan noght seen a balke
(base) ¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
(base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
(base) Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
(base) Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
(base) And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
(base) A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
(base) As any pecok he was proud and gay
(base) pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete
(base) And torne coppes and wel wrastle and sheete
(base) And by his belt he baar a long panade
(base) And of a swerd ful trenchaunt was the blade
(base) A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
(base) Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
(base) A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose
(base) Round was his face and camuse was his nose
(base) As piled as an Ape was his skulle
(base) He was a Market beter at the fulle
(base) Ther dorste no wight hand vp on hym legge
(base) That he ne swoor he sholde anon abegge
(base) A theef he was for sothe of corn and mele
(base) And that a sleigh and vsant for to stele
(base) His name was hoten deynous Symkyn
(base) A wif he hadde comen of noble kyn
(base) The person of the toun hir fader was
(base) With hir he yaf ful many a panne a bras
(base) For that Symkyn sholde in his blood allye

div.l: (base) She was yfostred in a Nonnerye
(base) For Symkyn wolde no wyf as he sayde
(base) But she were wel ynorissed and a mayde
(base) To sauen his estaat of yemanrye
(base) And she was proud and peert as is a pye
(base) A ful fair sighte was it vp on hem two
(base) On halidayes biforn hir wolde he go
(base) With his tipet wounden aboute his heed
(base) And she cam after in a gyte of reed
(base) And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
(base) Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame
(base) Was noon so hardy that wente by the weye
(base) That with hire dorste rage or ones pleye
(base) But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
(base) With panade or with knyf or boydekyn
(base) For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo
(base) Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so
(base) And eek for she was som del smoterlich
(base) She was as digne as water in a dich
(base) And ful of hoker and of bismare
(base) Hir thoghte that a lady sholde hir spare
(base) What for hir kynrede and hir nortelrye
(base) That she hadde lerned in the Nonnerye
(base) A doghter hadde they bitwix hem two
(base) Of twenty yeer with outen any mo
(base) Sauyng a child that was of hal yeer age
(base) In Cradel it lay and was a propre page
(base) This wenche thikke and wel ygrowen was
(base) With camuse nose and eyen greye as glas
(base) With buttokes brode and brestes rounde and hye
(base) But right fair was hir heer I wol nat lye
(base) The person of the toun for she was so feir
(base) In purpos was to maken hir his heir
(base) Bothe of his catel and his Mesuage
(base) And straunge he made it of hir mariage
(base) His purpos was to makyn hir his eire
(base) His purpos was for to bistowe hir hye
(base) In to som worthy blood of Auncetrye
(base) For holicherches good moot been despended
(base) On holicherches blood that is descended
(base) Ther fore he wolde his holy blood honoure
(base) Thogh that he holy chirche sholde deuoure
(base) Greet sokne hath this Miller out of doute
(base) With whete and malt of al the land aboute
(base) And nameliche ther was a greet Collegge
(base) Men clepeth the soler halle at Cantebregge
(base) Ther was hir whete and eek hir malt ygrounde

div.l: (base) And on a day it happed in a stounde
(base) Syk was this maunciple on a maladie
(base) Men wenden wisly that he sholde dye
(base) For which this Millere stal bothe mele and corn
(base) An hondred tyme moore than biforn
(base) For ther biforn he stal but curteisly
(base) But now he was a theef outrageously
(base) For which the wardeyn chidde and made fare
(base) But ther of sette the Millere noght a tare
(base) He craked boost and swoor it was noght so
(base) Thanne were ther yonge poure scolers two
(base) That dwelten in the halle of which I seye
(base) Testyf they were and lusty for to pleye
(base) And oonly for hir myrthe and reuerye
(base) Vp on the wardeyn bisily they crye
(base) To yeue hem leue but a litel stounde
(base) To go to Mille and seen hir corn ygrounde
(base) And hardily they dorste leye hir nekke
(base) The Millere sholde noght stelen hem half a pekke
(base) Of corn by sleighte ne by force hem reue
(base) And at the laste the wardeyn yaf hem leue
(base) Iohn highte that oon and Aleyn highte that oother
(base) Of oon town were they born that highte Strother
(base) Fer in the North I kan noght telle where
(base) This Aleyn maketh redy al his gere
(base) They makyn redy al hir owen gere
(base) And on an hors the sak he caste anon
(base) Forth gooth Aleyn the clerk. and also Iohn
(base) With good swerd and with bokeler by his syde
(base) Iohn knew the wey hym neded no gyde
(base) And at the Mille the sak adoun he layth
(base) Aleyn spak first alhayl Symkyn in fayth
(base) How fares thy faire doghter and thy wyf
(base) Aleyn wel come quod Symkyn by my lyf
(base) And Iohn also how now what do ye here
(base) By god quod Iohn . Symond nede has na peere
(base) Hym bihoues serue hym self that has na swayn
(base) Or ellis he is a fool as clerkes sayn
(base) Oure maunciple I hope he wol be deed
(base) Swa werkes ay the wanges in his heed
(base) And ther fore is I come and eek Alayn
(base) To grynde oure corn and carie it heem agayn
(base) I pray yow speed vs heythen what ye may
(base) It shal be doon quod Symkyn by my fay
(base) What wol ye doon whil that it is in hande
(base) By god right by the hoper wol I stande
(base) Quod Iohn and se how the corn gas In
(base) Yet saw I neuere by my fader kyn
(base) How that the hoper wagges til and fra
