Allas þis noble Ianuar þat is so free
A mydde his luste and his prosꝑper/parite
Is wexen blynde and al sodeynly ¶þ
His deeth þer for desireth he al vttirlye
And þer with al þe fyr of Ialowsye
Leste þat his wiffe schuld fal in som folye
So brente his herte þat he wolde fayne
That som man hir and hym hadde slayne
For neủer/re aft his deeth ne in his lyffe
Ne wolde he þat sche wer loue ne wyffe
But eủer/re liff as a wydowe in clothes blakke
Soule as þe turtil with þat hath loste hir make
But at þe laste aft̉er/re a monethe or tweye
His sorowe gan to swage sothe for to seye
For when he wiste it myȝht non oþer be
He paciently toke his aduersite
Saf oute of doute May he nolde for gone
For he was Ielouse eủer/remor in one
Whiche Ialousie was so outracheous
That neiþ̉er/re in hal ne in non other house
He nolde suffr hir for to ride ner goo
Ne in none oþer place neuer þe moo
But ȝif þat he had honde on hir alweye
For whiche wel ofte wepith fressh maye
That louyth Damyan so benignly
That sche mot either deye sothenly
Or els sche mot han hym at hir liste
She wayteth when her herte wolde to breste
Vpon þat oþ̉er/re side damyane
By comen is þe sorowfulleste man
That eủer/re was for neủer/re nyȝht nor daye
Ne myȝht he speke oo worde to fressh maye
As to his purpose of non swiche matier
But ȝiff þat Ianuar moste it her
That had oon honde opon hir eủer/re moo
And natheles be writyng to and froo
And pryue signes wiste he what she mente
And sche knewe of þe sygne of his entente
O Ianuar what myȝht it þe availle
Thowe myȝhteste see as ferr as schippes saille
For als good is to a blynde man disseyued be
As to be disseyuede when a man may see
Loo Arguys whiche þat had an hundreth eyen
For al þat eủer/re he couthe pour or pryen
Ȝit was he blente and god wote so bene moo
That wenen ful wysly þat it is not soo
Passe ouer is an ese and say no mor
This fressh may of whiche I spake of ȝor ¶þ
In warme wexe hathe enprynted þis cleket
That Ianuar bar of þat litil wyket
By whiche vn to his gardyn ofte he wente
And damyan þat knewe hir entente
The cliket countrefetid priuely
Ther nys no mor to saye but hastily
Som wonder be þis cliked schal betyde
Whiche ȝe schul heren ȝif ȝe wol abide
¶ O noble ouyde soith seiste þou god wote

rdg.seg:
What sleiȝht is it þof it
be longe and hote

div.l: That he nyl fynde it oute in som maner
By piramus and tysbe may men ler
Thof þei wer kepte ful longe streyte oủer/re al
Thei bene acorded rownynge thurgh þe wal
Ther is no wyȝhte þat couthe han founde oute suche a sleiȝhte
But nowe to purpose er þat daies eyȝte
Wer passede or þe moneth of Iuyl be fille
That Ianuarie hath cauȝht so grete a wille
Thurgh eggynge of his wyffe hym for to pleye
In his gardyn and none but þei tweye
That in a morwe vn to his may saide he
Rise up my wiffe my luff my lady free
The turtlys voys is herde my douse swete
The wynter is gone with al his reignes wete
Come forth nowe with þine eyen fair columbyne
Howe fairer bene þi brestis þan is þe wyne
The gardyn is enclosed al a boute
Come forth white spouse oute of dowte
Thou haste me wounded in myn herte o wyffe
No spotte in þe nas neủer/re in al þi liffe
Come forth and lat us take our desporte
I chees þe for my wyffe and my comforte
Suche olde lewde wordes vsed he
On damyan a signe made sche
That he schuld go be forne with his cliket
This damyan hath opynhed þe wyket
And in he stirte and þat in suche maner
That no wyȝht myȝht it see nor her
And stil he sitte vndir a bussh onon
This Ianuar so blynde is as a stone
With mayus in his hande and no wiȝht moo
In to his fressh gardyn is he goo
And clapped to þe wyket sothenly
Nowe wyff qd he her nys but þou and I
That arte þe creatur þat I beste loue
For by þat lorde þat sitte us alle aboue
I hadde leủer/re deyen on a knyffe ¶
Then þe offenden my der trewe wyffe
For goddes sake thenke howe I þe chees
Noȝht for no couetise douteles
But only for þe hie loue I hadde to þe
And þof þat I be olde and may not see
Be to me trewe and I wol tel ȝowe why
Certes thr thynges schullen ȝe wynne þer by
Firste loue of Criste and to ȝour selfe honour
And al myn heritage toun and tour
I ȝiff it ȝowe makith charters as ȝowe liste
This schal be do to morowe er þe son go to reste
So wisly god my soule brynge in blisse
I preye ȝowe on couenᵃnt þat ȝe me kysse
And þof I be gelous wyte me nouȝte
Ȝe bene so depe enpnted in my thouȝhte
That when þat I consider ȝour beaute
And þer with al þe vnlikhede of me
I may not Certes þof I schuld dye
For ber to bene oute of ȝour companye
For verrey loue þat is with outen doute
Nowe kisse me wiffe and lat us rome aboute
This fressh may when sche þise wordes herde
Benygly to Ianuar scho answerde
But firste and forwarde sche began to wepe
I haue qd sche a soule for to kepe
Als wele as ȝe and also myn honour
And of my wiffhede þilke tender flour
Whiche þat I haf assured in ȝour hande
When þat þe preste to ȝowe my body bande
Wher for I wol answer in þis maner
With þe leue of ȝowe my lorde so der
I pray god þat neủer/re dawe þat daye
þat I ne starfe as foule as eny wōmman may
Ȝiff eủer/re I do vn to my kynne þat schame
Or els þat I enpeir so my name
That I be fals and if I doo þat lakke
Do stripe me and putte me in a sakke
And in þe nexte riuer do me drenche
I am a gentil wōmman and no wenche
Why speke ȝe þus but men bene eủer/re vntrewe
And wōmmen hauen repreve of ȝowe ay newe
Ȝe can non oþ̉er/re 9tinaunce I leue
But speke to us as vntriste and repue
And with þat worde sche sawe wher damyan
Sat in þe bussh and knele he began ¶þ
And with hir fyng sygnes made sche
That damyan schuld clymbe up on atr
That charchet was with fruyte and up he wente
For verrely he knewe al hir entente
And eủer/rey signe þat sche couthe make
Wel bett̉er/re þan Ianuar hir own make
For in a lett̉er/re sche had tolde hym al
Of þis mat̉er/re howe he worchen schal
And þus I lete hym sitte in þe pirye
And Ianuarie and mayus rownyng ful mery
Briȝht was þe daye and blewe þe firmamente
Phebus of golde doun hath his stremes sente
To gladen eủer/rey flour with his warmenesse
He was þat tyme in gemynys as I gesse
But litil fro his declinacoıı̄un
Off canser Iouis exaltacoıı̄un
And so be fel þat in a briȝht morwetyde
That in þe gardyn in þe ferþer side
Pluto þat is þe kynge of fairee
And mony a lady in his companye
Folowynge his wyffe þe quene ꝓprosarpina
Whiche þat he rauysshed oute of ꝓproserpina
Whils þat sche gadered flowres in a mede
In claudyan ȝe may þe stories rede
Howe in his grysly carte he hir sette
The kynge of fayr a doun hym sette
O pon a benche of tornys Fressh and grene
And riȝht onone said he þus to his quene
My wyff qd he þat may not say nay
The exꝑper/parience proueth it eủer/rey day
The tresoun whiche þat womēmn don to man
Ten hundreth thousande tellen I can
Notable of ȝour vntrowthe and brotelnes
O salon richeste of al riches
Fulfilled of sapience and of worldly glorie
Ful worthy ben þi wordes to memorie
To eủer/rey wiȝht þat wytte and resoun can
Thus piseth he ȝit þe bonte of man
Amonge a thousand men ȝit fonde I one
But of alle wōmmen fonde he neủer/re none
Thus seith þis kynge þat knoweth ȝoᵘur wykednes
And Ihc filius Cyrak as I gesse
Ne speketh of ȝowe but selden reủer/reence ¶þ
A wilde fuyr a corrupte pestilence
So fal opon ȝour bodies ȝit to nyȝht
Ne se ȝe not þis honurable knyȝhte
Be cause allas þat he is blynde and olde
His own man schal make hym cokewolde
Loo wher he sitte þe lycchour in þe tr
Nowe wol I graunte of my maieste
Vn to þis olde blynde worthy knyȝhte
That he schal haf a ȝeyn his eyen siȝhte

l.seg: But cause allas þat he is blynde and olde

div.l: When þat his wiff wol done hym vilanye
Than schal he knowen alle his harlotrye
Both in reproffe of hir and oþ̉er/re moo
Ȝa schal qd proserpen and wol ȝe soo
Nowe be my moders sires soule I swer
That I schal ȝiffen hir suffisaunt answer
And al wōmmen aft̉er/re for ȝour sake
That þof þei bene in any gilte y take
With face bolde þei schul hem selfe excuse
And ber hem doun þat wolden hem accuse
For lakke of answer non of hem schal dien
Al hadde ȝe seie a thynge with both ȝour eyen
Ȝit schullen we so visage it hardyly
And wepe and swer and chide subtily
That ȝe schul bene as lewed as her geese
What rekketh me of ȝour auctoritees
I wote wele þis Iew þis salon
Fonde of us wōmmen folies mony one
But þof þat he fonde ne goode woman
Ther hath y founde mony a noþ̉er/re man
Wyme ful goode ful trewe ful vertuos
Witnes on hem þat dwellen in Cristꝭes hous
With martirdome þei proved hir constance
The romeyn gestis maken remembraunce
Off mony a verrey trewe wyffe also
But sir ne be not wrooth as be it soo
¶ Þof þat he saide he fonde ne goode woman
I pray ȝowe take þe sentence of þe wise man
He mente þus þat in souereigne bounte
Nys none but god but neþ̉er/re he ne sche
Eye for verray godde þat nys but one
What make ȝe so muche of salon
What þof he made a temple goddis hous
What þof he wer riche and glorious ¶þ
So made he a temple of fals goddes
Who myȝth do eny thynge þat mor forbode is
ꝐPer/Parde as fair has he his name in plastr
He was a lichour and an ydolastr
And in his elde he verrey good forsoke
And ȝif þat god ne hadde as seith þe booke
Y spared hym for his fadres sake he scholde
Haf loste his reigne souner þan he wolde
I sette not of al þe vilenye
That he of wymmen writeth not a butt̉er/reflye
I am a wōmman nedes mote I speke
Ouþ̉er/re hellys swel til myn herte breke
For sethens he saide þat we bene Ianglers
As eủer/re mote I brouke bothe my tresses
I schal not spar for no curtesie
To speke hym harme þat wolde us vilanye
Dame qd þis pluto be no leng wroothe
I ȝiff it up but sethens I swor myn othe
That I wolde graunte hym his siȝht a ȝeyn
My worde schal stande þat warne I þe c̉er/reteyn
I am a kynge it sitteth me not for to lye
And I qd sche a quene am of fayrye /
Hir answer sche schal haf I vndirtake
Lete us no moo wordes make
For sothe I wol no lenger ȝowe contᵃrie
Nowe lete us turne a ȝeyn to Ianuarie
That in þis gardyn with þis fair maye
Syngeth ful merier þan þe popin Ieye
Ȝowe luff I beste and schal and oþ̉er/re none
So longe a boute þe aleys is he gone
Til he was com a gayns þilk pirie
Wher as þis damyan sitteth ful merye
On hiegh amonge þe fressh leves grene
This fressh may þat is so briȝht and schene
Gan for to sike and saide allas my side
Nowe sir qd sche for ouȝht þat may betyde
I moste haue of þe pieres þat I see
Or I mot dye so sor longeth me
To eten of þe smale peres grene
Helpe for hir loue þat is of heuen quene
I tel ȝowe wele a wōmman in my plyte
May haf to fruyte so grete an appetite ¶þ
That sche may deyen but sche it hafe
Allas qd he þat I ne had her a knaue
That couthe clymbe allas allas qd he
For I am blynde ȝa sir no force qd sche
But wolde ȝe wouche saue for goddis sake
The piry with in ȝour armes to take
For wele I wote þat ȝe mystruste me
Than schuld I clymbe wel ynogh ꝙquod sche
So I my fote myȝht sette opon ȝour bakke
For sothe saide he in me schal be no lakke
Miȝht I ȝowe helpe with myn herte blode
He stoupeth doun and on his bak sche stode
And cauȝht hir be a twiste and up sche goith
Ladys I praye ȝowe þat ȝe be not wroothe
I can not glose I am a rude man
And sodenly onon þis damyan
Gan pullen up þe smokke and in he thronge
And whan þat pluto sagh þis grete wronge
To Ianuarye he ȝaf his sight a ȝeyne
Ne was þ̉er/re neủer/re man of thynge so fayn
But on his wyffe his thoȝht was eủer/remoo
Vp to þe tr he keste his eyen twoo .
And seigh þat damyan his wyff had dressede
In whiche man it may not be expressede
But if I wolde speke vncurteisly
And up he ȝaf a rorynge and a crye
As doith þe moder when þe child schal dye
Oute help allas harrowe he gan to crie
O strong lady stour what dost þou
And sche answered sir what eyleth ȝowe
Haue pacience and resoıı̄un in ȝour mynde
I haf ȝowe holpen on both ȝour eyen blynde
Vp on ꝑper/paril of my soule I schal not lyen
As me was tauȝht to hele with ȝour eyen
Was no thynge bette for to make ȝowe see
Than strogle with a man opon a tr
God woote I did it in ful goode entente
Strogle ꝙquod he ȝa algat in it wente
God ȝiff ȝowe bothe on schames deth for to deyen
He swyffed þe I sagh it with myn eyen
And els be I honged be þe hals
Than is qd sche þe medcyn fals
For certenly if þat ȝe myȝhten see ¶þ
Ȝe wolde not seye þo wordes vn to me
Ȝe han som glymysynge and no ꝑper/parfite siȝht
I see qd he als wele as eủer/re I myȝht
Thanked be god with both myn eyen twoo
And be my trouthe me thouȝht he did ȝow soo
Ȝa maase mase gode sir qd sche
This thank haf I for I haf made ȝowe see
Allas qd sche þat eủer/re I was so kynde
Nowe dame qd he let al passe oute of mynde
Come down my leue and if I haf myssaide
God helpe me so as I am euyl apaiede
But be my faders soule I wende haf seyn
Howe þat þis damyan had with ȝowe leyn
And þat ȝour smoke had leyn opon ȝour breste
Ȝe sir qd sche ȝe may wene as ȝowe liste
But sir a man þat waketh oute of his slepe
He may not sothenly wel take kepe
Opon a thynge ne seen it ꝑper/parfitely
Til þat he be a dawed verraly
Riȝht so a man þat longe hath blynde y be
Ne may not sodenly so wele see
Firste when þe siȝht is newe comen a gayn
As he þat hath a day or tweye y seyne
Til þat ȝour syȝhte y stabled be a while
Ther may ful mony a siȝhte ȝowe be gile
Beth war I pray ȝowe for by þe heuen kynge
Ful mony man weneth for to see a thynge
And it is al a noþ̉er/re þan it semeth
He þat mys 9ceyueth oftymes a mys he demeth
And with þat worde sche lepe doun fro þe tr
This Ianuar who is gladde but he
He kisseth hir and clippeth hir ful ofte
And on hir wombe he stroketh hir ful softe
And to his paleys home he hath hir ladde
Nowe gode men I praye ȝowe to be gladde
Thus endeth her my tale of Ianuarie
God blesse us and his moder seynt Marie Amen
¶ Here endeth þe marchauntz tale
¶ Here begynneth þe ꝓprologe . of . þe . wyffe of Bathe
Exꝑper/parimente thogh non auctorite
Wer in þis worlde is riȝht ynogh for me
To speke of wo þat is in mariage
For lordynges seth I twelff ȝer was of age .
Thanked be god þat is et̉er/rene alyue
Husbondes atte chirche dor I haf hadde fyue
Ȝiff I so often myȝht haue wedded be
But alle wer worthy men in her degr .
But me was tolde certeyn not longe agons
That sithen Criste ne wente neủer/re but ones /
To weddynge in þe Cane of galilee .
That by þilke ensample tauȝht he me /
That I ne schuld wedded be but ones
Herke eke / loo whiche a scharpe worde for þe / nones
Be side a wel . Ihu godde and man
Spak in repffe of þe samaritan
Thow haste y hadde v. husbondes qd he .
And þat ilke man þat nowe hathe þe .
Is not / þine husbonde þus saide / he c̉er/reteyn /
What he mente þerby I can not seyne
Wele but þat I axe why þe .v. manne
Was none husbonde to þe samaritane
Howe mony myȝht sche han in mariage
Ȝit herde I neuer tel in myn age /
O pon þis nombr diffinicioıı̄un
Men may diuine and glosen up and doune
But wele I wote expsse with outen lye
God bad us for to wexe and multiplie
That gentiel texte can I wele vndirstonde
Eke wele I wote he saide myn husbonde
Schuld lete fader and moder and take / to me
But of no nombr mencioun made he
Of bigamye or of octogamye
Why schuld men þan seyn of it vilenye
Looke her þe wise man kynge salamoıı̄un
I trowe / he hadde wyffes mo þan one /
Nowe wold god it leful wer to me
To be refresshed half so ofte as he
Whiche ȝifte of godde hadde he for al his wyffes
No man hath suche þᵗat in þis worlde a / lyffe is
God wote þis noble kynge as to / my wytte
The firste nyȝht hadde mony a mery fitte /
With iche of hem so wele was hym a lyue .
Blessed be god þat I haf wedded fyffe
Welcome þe sexte when þat eủer/re he schal
For soth I wil not kepe chaste in al
When myn husbonde is fro þe worlde gone
Sum cristen man schal wedde me onon
For þan þe Apostel seith þat I am fr
To wedde on goddis halfe wher it liketh / me
He seith for to be wedded is no synne /
Better it is to be wedded þan for to brenne
What rekketh me þof folke saye vilanye
Of schrewed lameth and his bygamye
I wote wele Abraham was an holy man
And Iacob eke as ferr as eủer/re I can
And / iche of hem hadde wyffes mo þan twoo
And mony a noþ̉er/re holy man also
Wher can ȝe say in eny man age
That god defended / us . mariage /
By expsse worde I pray ȝowe tellith me
Or wher 9maunded he virginite
I wote as wele as ȝe it is no drede
The Apostel when he speketh of maydenhede
He saide þerof precepte hadde he none
Men may 9seil a wōmman to liff allone
But 9seillynge is no 9mandement
He putte it / in our own iuggemente /
For hadde god 9maunded maydenhode
Then hadde he dampned weddyng with þe dede
And certis ȝif þ̉er/re wer no sede y sowe
Virginite þan wher of schuld it growe /
Poule durste not / 9maunden at þe leste
A thynge of whiche his maist̉er/re ȝaf hym non heste
The darte is sette up for virginitee
Chase who so may who so renneth best lat see
But þis worde / is noȝt take of eủer/rey wyȝhte
But þer as god wolde ȝiff it of his myȝht
I wote wele þat þe Apostel was a mayde
But nathelesse þof þat he wrote or seide /
He wolde þat eủer/rey wyȝhte wer suche as he /
Al nys not but 9seil to virginite
And for to be a wyffe he ȝaff me leue /
Of indulgence / so it is no repreue
To wedde me ȝif þat my make deye
With oute excepcioıı̄un of bigamye
Al wer it goode no man forto touche
He mente as his body or in his couche
For ꝑper/paril it is / both fir and towe to assemble
Ȝe knowe what þis / ensample may ressemble
This al and some he helde virginite
Mor ꝑper/parfite þan wedded in freeltee
Freelte clepe I not but þat he and sche
Wolde lede her liffe al in chastite /
I graunt it wele I haf none envie
Thogh maydenhede pferr bygamye
It liketh hem to be clene in body and goste
Of myne astate I wol make no boste
For wele ȝe knowe a lorde in his howsholde
Hath not eủer/rey vessel of golde
Some bene of tr and done her lorde seruise
God clepith folke to hym in sundry wyse /
And eủer/reichon hath of godde a ꝓpropr ȝifte
Som þis som þat as hym liketh to schyfte
Virginite is grete ꝑper/parfectioıı̄un
And continence eke with deuocoıı̄un
But criste þat of ꝑper/parfectioun is wel
Bad not eủer/rey wyȝht he schuld sel
Al þat he hadde and ȝiff it to þe por /
And in suche wise folowe hym and his lor
He spake to hem þat wolde liff ꝑper/parfitely /
And lordynges be ȝour leue þat am not I
I wol be stowe þe flour of al myn age
In charite and fruyte of mariage
Tell me also to what conclusioıı̄un
Wer membres made of generacoıı̄un
And of so ꝑper/parfite wyse / and why y wroȝht
Trusteth riȝht wele þei wer not made for noȝte
Glose who so wil and seye both up and doun
That þei wer made for purgacoıı̄un
Of vryne and our both þinges smale
Wer eke to knowe a female from a male
And for non oþ̉er/re cause what saye ȝe no
The exꝑper/parience wote it is / not soo

div.l: (base) ¶ The prologe of the Freres tale

Ther as myn herte is sete þ̉er/re wol I wyffe
And but ȝe wulen assente in suche maner
I pray ȝow speketh no mor of þis mater
¶ Withe hertly wil þei sworen and assenten
To al þis thynge þ̉er/re saide no wiȝht nay
Besechyng hym of grace er þei wenten
That he hem wolde granten a c̉er/retein daye
Of his spousail as sone as eủer/re he may
For ȝit alweye þe peple sum what dredde
Leste þus markeys wold no wyff wedde
He gʳnted hem a daye swiche as hym luste ¶þ
On whiche he wold be wedded sikirly
And said he did al þis at her requeste
And thei with humble entent ful buxomily
Kneling vpon her knees ful rev̉er/reently
Hym thankyn alle and thus þei han an ende
Of her entente and hoom aȝeyn þei wende
¶ And her vpon he toke his officers
Comaundynge for þe feste to pʳueie
And to his priue knyghtes and squirs
With suche charge ȝaf hem as luste on hem to leye
And þei his comandementes to obeie
And eche of hem doth his diligence .
To done vnto þe feste reủer/reence
xouȝt fer from þilke place honurable
Wher as þe markeys shepe his mariage
Ther stoode a thrope of site delitable
In whiche por folke of þat vilage
Hadden hir bestes and her herbigage
And of her labour toke hir sustenance
Aft̉er/re þat þe erthe hem ȝaf habundaunce
¶ Amonge þis por̉er/re folke þer dwelled a maıı̄un
Whiche þat was holden þe porest of hem alle
But hie god somtyme sende can .
His grace vnto a litel Oxe stalle
Ianicula men of þat threp hym calle .
A dought̉er/re had he fair and ȝonge of sighte .
And Griseld þis ȝonge mayden heighte
But for to speke of vertuos beautee
Than was she one þe fayrest vnder sonne
Wel pouerly y fostred was she
No likeroluss was on hir liste y ronne .
wele oft̉er/re of þ wel þan of þe tonne .
She dranke and for she wold vertue please
She knewe wel labour but none ydel ese
But þoȝ þis mayde wer tendir of age
Ȝit in þe breste of hir virginite
Ther was enclosed ripe and sadde corage .
And in grete reueronce and grete charitee .
Hir olde pouer fader fostred she .
A fewe shepe spynnynge on þe folde she kepte
She wolde not bene idel til she slepte
¶ And when she homwarde come she wold brynge
Wortes and erbes tymes ful ofte
Whiche she shrad and seth for hir lyffynge .
And made hir bedde ful ofte and no thynge softe
And eủer/re she keped her fader liff on lofte .
With evʳy obeisaunce and diligence
That any childe miȝht do to þe faders reuerence
¶ Vpon Griselde þe pore creature
Wel ofte hathe þe markeys sate his eye .
As he on huntynge roode ꝑper/parauentur .
And whāmn it fel þat he myȝht hir aspie .
He not with wantōmn lekynge of folye .
his eyen caste vp on hir but in sad wise .
Vpon hir chere he wolde hym ofte auise
¶ Commendyng in his herte hir womanhede
And eke her vertue passing any wight .
Of so ȝonge age as wele in cher as in dede .
For þof þe peple haue no grete insight .
In vertue he considered it full right .
Hir bounte and disposed þat he wolde .
Hir wedde if eủer/re he wedde sholde
¶ The day of weddynge came but no wight can
Tell what woman it shuld be .
For which meruaille wondred many man .
And seden whāmn þei where in priuete .
Wol not our lorde leue his vanite .
Wil je not wedde allas allas þe while .
Why wil je hym selfe and vs þus bigile
¶ But nathelesse þis markeys hath do make
Of gemmes sate in golde and of asur .
Broches and rynges for Griseld sake .
And of hir chothynge toke he þe mesur .
Of a mayden like to hir stature .
And eke of oþ̉er/re ornamentes alle .
That to suche a weddynge shuld falle
¶ The tyme of vndrene in þe same daye
Approcheth þat þis weddynge shuld be
And all þe palays putte was in araye ¶þ
Both halle and chambres eche in his degree
Howse of office stuffed with grete plente .
Ther maist þou se of deyntewus vitalle .
That may be fonde as fare as lasteth ytaille
¶ This roial markys ally arraiede
Lordes and ladies in his compainye . an
Þe whiche to þe feste wher prayed .
and of his retenue þe bachilrye .
With many a somn of sundry melodye .
Vn to þe village which I tolde .
In þis aray ye right way þei holde
¶ Griselde god wote of þis ful innocente
That for her was shape al þis araye .
To fechen water at þe welle is wente .
And comyth home as sone as eủer/re she may .
For wele she herde sey þat ilke daye .
That markeis shulde wedde and if she myȝht
She wold fayn seen som of þat siȝht
¶ She thouȝht I wol with oþ̉er/re maydens stonde
That bene my felaws in our dore and see .
The Markeys and þer for wol I fonde .
To done at hom als sone as it may be.
The labour whiche þat longeth to me .
And þan may I at laiser it beholde .
If she þis waye to þe castel holde
And as she wolde oủer/re þe th̉er/resswolde gone
The markys come and gan hir for to cal .
And she sete doun hir water potts anon.
Beside þe thressholde of þe oxe stalle .
And doun vpon hir knees she gan to falle .
And with sadde countence kneled stil .
Til she had herde what was þe lordes wil
¶ This thoughtful markeys spake vn to þis mayde
We soberly and saide in þis maner .
Wher is ȝour fader Griselde he saide .
And she with reuerence and with ful mylde cher
Answered lorde he is al redy her .
And in she goith with outen leng lette .
And to þe markeys she hire fader fette ¶þ
He by þe hande tan toke þis olde man
An saide þus when he hym hadde in side .
Ianicula I neither may ne can .
Lenger þe plesaunce of myn herte hide .
If þat ȝe wouchesaue what so betyde .
Thi doȝhter wol I take er þat I wende .
As for my wyffe in wedloke to my liffes ende
¶Thou louest me I wote wele certeyn
And art my faithfuls liege man ybor .
And al þat liketh me I dar wele seyn .
It liketh þe and specially þerfore .
Tell me þat poynt þat I haf saide be for .
If þat þou wolt vn to þat purpose drawe
To take me as for þi son in lawe
¶ The sodeyn caas þs man asonyed so
That reede he wepe al bashed and al quakynge
He stode vnnethe he seide wordes moo.
But only þid lotfr qd he my willynge .
Is as ȝe wol noth aȝeins ȝour likynge .
I wol no thynge ȝe be my lorde so der
Riȝht as ȝowe liste gouʳneth þis mater
¶ Than wol I do þis qd þs markeys softely
That in to þi chambr I and you and she .
Haue a collacioıı̄un and wotost you why .
For I will aske ȝif hir wil be .
To be my wyffe and reule hir aft̉er/re me .
And alle þis she shal done in þi psence
I wil not speke it oute of þine audience
¶ An in þe chambr whil þei wer aboute
Hir retys whiche ȝe shul aft̉er/re her .
The peple came in to ᵗe house with oute .
And wondred hem in howe honest maner
And tentifly she kepte hir fader der .
But vtterly Griseld wondred mych .
For neủer/re efte she sawe of siȝht non suche .
¶ Noo wonder is þot she is stonyede
To see so grete a geste com in to þat plase
She was neủer/re to swich grestys woned .
For whiche she loked with ful pale face
But shortly fro þis mat̉er/re for to pase ¶þ
This werthe wordes þat is markeys saide
To þis benigne verrey faithful maide
¶ Griseld he seide ȝe shol wele vnderstonde
It liketh vn to ȝour fader and me .
That I ȝowe wedde and eke it may so stonde .
As I suppose þat ȝe wil þat it so be .
But þis demᵃnde I aske firste qd he .
that sithen it shal be doıı̄un on hastyff wise
Wol ȝe assent or ells ȝowe auise
¶ I seye þis be ȝe redy with goode herte
To all my luste and þat I frely may .
As me beste thynketh do ȝowe lagh or smerte
And ȝe neủer/re grucche nyȝht ne daye .
And eke whan I seyye ȝa ȝe sey not naye .
Neither by wode ne fowarde contenᵃnce
Swer þis and her I swer our alyaunce .
¶ Wondrynge vpon þis worde quakynge for drede
She said vndine and vnworthy
Am I to þat þat ȝe me bede
But riȝht as ȝe wol ȝour selfe riȝht so wol I .
And I swer þat neủer/re wyllyngly
In wrode ne in thouȝht shal neủer/re ȝowe disobeye
For to be ded þof me wer loth to dye
¶ Thi is ynowgh Griseld myn gd he
And forth he goth with a sobr chere .
Out at þe dor aft̉er/re come she .
And to ᵗe peple he said on þis maner .
This is my wyffe qd he þat stondeth her .
Honureth her and loueth hir þ̉er/re is no mor to say
Who so loueth me . hertly I ȝowe praye
¶ And for nothynge of hir olde ger
She shulde brynge to his house he badde
That women shulden spoille hir riȝht þer
Of whiche þs ladies wer riȝht gladde
To handel hir clothes in whiche she was
But natheles þis maide briȝht of hewe
Fro foote to heede yclothed han al newe
¶ Hir heres han thei kombed þat lay vntressed
Ful rudely with hir fyngers smale .
And a crown on hir hede þei hane dressed ¶þ
And sette it ful of owches grete and smale
Of hir aray what shulde I make a tale .
Vnneth þe peple hir knowe for hir fairnesse
Whan she transformed was in suche richesse
¶ This markeys hath her spoused with a rynge
Broȝht for þhe same cause and þane hir sete .
Vpon an hors snowe white and wele amblynge
And to his palys er he lenger lete .
With ioyful peple þat he ladde and mette .
Conoyed hir and thus e day þei spende .
In reuel til þe sonne gan desende
¶ And shortly forth þis tale for to chase
I say þat to þis newe markeisesse .
God hath y sente swiche fauour of his gʳce.
Þat is semed not as by likenesse .
That she was borne and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in an oxe stalle .
But norrysshed in an emꝑper/paroures halle .
¶ To eủer/rey wyȝht she woxen is so der
And worshipfull þat folke þ̉er/re she was bor
And from hir burthe knewe hir from ȝer to ȝer
Vnnethe trowed þei but dorste haf swore
That to Ianicle of þed whiche I spak befor
She douȝhtr ne wer for as by coniectur
Hem thouȝht she was an other creatur
¶ For þat eủer/remor vertuose was . she .
She was encresed in swiche excellence
Of thewes sette in heigh bountee .
And so discrete and fair of elouence
So benigne and digne of reủer/reence .
And couthe þe peple hert so embrase .
That eche hir loued þat loked on hir face
¶ Nouȝt only of saluce in þe town
Publisshed was þe bounte of hir name
Budeke beside in mony a regioun
If one saide wel another said þe same
So sprad of hir bounte þe fame
That men and women both ȝong and olde
Gon to Saluce hir to beholde ¶þ
¶ This Walt lowly luffaih and ryaily
Weddeth with fortune honeste .
In goddes eese liffeth ful hesily .
At home and outewarde was ynogh hade he .
And for he saw vnder low degree .
Was ofte vertu hidde þe peple hym helde
A prudent man and þat is seine wel selde
¶ Nouȝht only þus Griseld thurgh hir wytte
Touche al þe feete of wyfely humblenes .
But eke when þe caas required it .
The cōmmune ꝓprofite couthe she redresse .
Ther no was discorde ranceur ne heuynesse .
In al þe londe þat she ne coude it ese .
And brynge hem al wysely in reste and ese .
¶ Thof þat hir husbonde presente wer or none
Yiff gentil men or other of hir countr
Wer wrothe she couthe brynge hem at one .
So wise and discrete wordes hadde she .
And Iuggement of so grete equitee .
That she from heuen was as mēmn wende .
ꝐPer/Parsente peple to saue and eủer/rey wronge to amende
¶ Nouȝt longe tyme aft̉er/re þat þis Griseld was wedded
She a fair daughter hath ybor
Al had she leid han leure a knaue childe .
Glad was þe markeys and his folke þerfor .
For þof a maydey childe come albefore
She may to a knaue shilde atteyne .
Be liklyed sethone she is not baren
¶ Therfor as it falleth tymes moo
Than this childe hath sowked but a throwe .
This markeys in his herte longeth soo .
To tempte his wyffe hir sadnes to knowe .
That he ne myȝht fro his herte throwe .
This merueylous desir his wyffe to assaye .
Natheles god wote he thouȝth hir to affraye
¶ He had assaied hir ynogh before
And fonde hir eủer/re goode what nedeth it .
Hir for to torment and alwey mor and mor .
Thof some mēmy preise it for a subtel wytte .
But as for me I sey þat euyl it site ¶þ
To assaie a wyffe whēmn it is no nede
And puten hir in anguissh and in drede
¶ For whiche tis markeys wroȝht on þis maner
He came a nyght allone þ̉er/re as she laye .
With serne face and trouble cher .
And said þus / Griselde qd he þat daye .
that I ȝouwe toke oute of your por aray .
And putte ȝowe in astate of he noblesse .
Ȝe hauen not ȝit forȝetēmn as I gesse
¶ I say Griselde þis presente dignite
In whiche I haf pute ȝowe as I trowe
Maketh not ȝowe foryetful to be
That I ȝowe toke in poủer/re etate ful lowe
For any thynge ȝe motte ȝour selfon knowe
Tak hede of eủer/rey worde þat I ȝowe saye
Ther is no wiȝht þat hereth þis but we tweye
Ye wote ȝour selfe wele howe þat ȝe come her
In to þis house it is not longe a goo .
And þof to me ȝe be lefe and dere .
Vn to my gentilesse ȝe be no thynge soo .
Thei seye to hem it is grete shame and woo
For to be subget and in seruage .
To þe þat art borne of so lowe lynage
¶ And namely seth þi dought̉er/re was bore
thise wordes hauēm þei spoke doutelesse .
But I desir as I haue done befor .
To liff my liffe with hem in reste and peese
I may not in þis caas bene recheles .
I must doıı̄un with þd dought̉er/re for þe beste .
Nought as I would but as my gentilesse liste
¶ And ȝit god wote þis is wel loth to me
But nathelesse with oute ȝour wytynge .
I wol not do but þis I wol qd he
that ȝe to me assent as in þis thynge .
Showeth moew ȝour pacience in ȝỏer/re thynge
that ȝe me beiȝht and swor in ȝore village
¶ That day þat maked was our mariage
When she had herd al þis she was not ameued
Nether in worde nor cher nor coutenᵃnce ¶þ
For as it demed she was not agreuede
She sad lorde al lieth your plesaunce .
My childe and I with hertly obesaunce .
Ben ȝoures al and ȝe may saue or spille
Your own thynge whether þat ȝe weyl
¶Ther may no thynge so god my soule saue
Likynge to ȝowe þat may displese me .
Ne I desir no thynge to haue .
Ne drede to lese saue only go .
This will is myn hert and ay shl be
No length of tyme or deth it may deface .
Nor chaunge my corage in to non other place
¶ Glad was þs markys for hir answeryng
But yet he feyned as he wer nat so .
Al drery was his cher and his lokyng .
When he shuld out of þe chambre go.
Soon aft̉er/re þs a furlange weye or two .
He priuely tolde alle his entente
Vnto a man and to him his wyf sente
A man seriaint was þis priuee māmn
The whiche þat feythfull founde he hadde .
In thynges grete and eke suche folke wel can .
Don execution of thynges badde .
The lorde knewe wele þat he hym loued and dradde
And when þis seriaunt wiste his lordes wil .
In to þe chamb̉er/re he salked hym full still
¶ Madame he said ȝe mote foryeue me
ꝒProoȝ I do þinge to whiche I am constreynede
Ȝe bene so wise þat wele knowen ȝe .
Þat lordes heses may not be fyned .
Þei mowe well be wailled or pleynede.
But man mote nede bn to her luste obeie .
And wo wol I þ̉er/re is no more to seye .
¶ This child I am cōmmanded for to take
And spak no mor but oute þe childe he hente .
Despitiously and gan a a cher to make .
As he wolde han slayn it er he wente .
Griseld mote alle suffre and alle sente.
And as a lambe she siteth meeke and stil .
And lete þis cruel seriaunt haf al his wyl
¶ Suspecious was þe fame of þis man
Suspect his face suspect his worde also. ¶þ
Suspect the tyme in which he this bigan
Allas hir doghter that she loued so
She wende he wolde han slayn it right tho
But nathelees she neither weep ne syked
Conformynge hire to that the Markys liked
But at the laste speken she bigan
And mekely she to the Sergeant preyde
So as he was a worthy gentil man
That she moste kisse hir child er that it deyde
And on hir barm this litel child she leyde
With ful sad face and gan the child to blesse
And lulled it and after gan it kesse
And thus she seyde in hir benygne voys
Fare wel my child I shal thee neuere see
But sith I thee haue marked with the croys
Of thilke fader blessed mote he be
That for vs deyde vp on a croys of tree
Thy soule litel child I hym bitake
For this nyght shaltow dyen for my sake
I trowe that to a Norice in this cas
It hadde been hard this routhe for to se
Wel myghte a moder haue cryd allas
But nathelees so sad stedefast was she
That she endured al aduersitee
And to the Sergeant mekely she sayde
Haue here agayn youre litel yonge mayde
Goth now quod she and doth my lordes heste
But o thyng wol I pray yow of youre grace
That but my lord forbad yow at the leeste
Burieth this litel body in som place
That bestes ne no bryddes it to race
But he no word wol to that purpos seye
But took the child and wente vp on his weye
This sergeant cam vn to his lord agayn
And of Grisildis wordes and hir cheere
He tolde hym poynt for poynt in short and playn
And hym persenteth with his doghter deere
Som what this lord hadde routhe in his manere
But nathelees his purpos held he stille
As lordes doon whan they wol han hir wille
And bad this Sergeant that he pryuely
Sholde this child softe wynde and wrappe
With alle circumstances tendrely
And carie it in a cofre or in a lappe
But vp on peyne his heed of for to swappe
That no man sholde knowe of this entente
Ne whennes he cam ne whider that he wente
But at Boloigne he to his suster deere
That thilke tyme of Pauyk was Countesse
He sholde it take and shewe hir this matere
Bisekynge hir to doon hir bisynesse
This child to fostre in alle gentilesse
And whos child that it was he bad hir hyde
From euery wight for aught that may bityde
The Sergeant goth and hath fulfild this thyng
But to this Markys now retourne we
For now goth he ful faste ymagynyng
If by his wyues cheere he myghte se
Or by hir word aperceyue that she
Were chaunged but he neuere hir koude fynde
But euere in oon ylike sad and kynde
As glad as humble as busy in seruyse
And eek in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in euery maner wise
Ne of hir doghter noght a word spak she
Noon accident for noon aduersitee
Was seyn in hir ne neuere hir doghter name
Ne nempned she in ernest ne in game

l.hi: Explicit tercia pars

div.l: Incipit pars quarta
IN this estat ther passed ben 4 yeer
Er she with childe was but as god wolde
A knaue child she bar by this Walter
Ful gracious and fair for to biholde
And whan that folk it to his fader tolde
Nat oonly he but al his contree merye
Was for this child and god they thanke and herye
Whan it was two yeer old and fro the brest
Departed of his Norice on a day
This Markys caughte yet another lest
To tempte his wyf yet ofter if he may
O nedelees was she tempted in assay
But wedded men ne knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature
Wyf quod this Markys ye han herd er this
My peple sikly berth this mariage
And namely sith my sone yborn is
Now is it worse than euere in al oure age
The murmur sleeth myn herte and my corage
For to myne erys comth the voys so smerte
That it wel neigh destroyed hath myn herte
Now sey they thus whan Walter is agon
Thanne shal the blood of Ianycle succede
And been oure lord for oother haue we noon
Swiche wordes seith my peple out of drede
Wel oghte I of swich murmur taken hede
For certeinly I drede swich sentence
Though they nat pleyn speke in myn audience
I wolde lyue in pees if that I myghte
Wherfore I am disposed outrely
As I his suster serued by nyghte
Right so thenke I to serue hym priuely
This warne I yow that ye nat sodeynly
Out of your self for no wo sholde outraye
Beth pacient and ther of I yow praye
I haue quod she seyd thus and euere shal
I wol no thyng ne nyl no thyng certeyn
But as yow list noght greueth me at al
Thogh that my doghter and my sone be sleyn
At youre comandement this is to seyn
I haue nat had no part of children tweyne
But first siknesse and after wo and peyne
Ye ben oure lord dooth with your owene thyng
Right as yow list axeth no reed of me
For as I lefte at hom al my clothyng
Whan I first cam to yow right so quod she
Lefte I my wyl and al my libertee
And took youre clothyng wher fore I yow preye
Dooth your plesance I wol youre lust obeye
And certes if I hadde prescience
Youre wyl to knowe er ye your lust me tolde
I wolde it doon with outen necligence
But now I woot youre lust and what ye wolde
Al your plesance ferm and stable I holde
For wiste I that my deeth wolde doon yow ese
Right gladly wolde I dyen yow to plese
Deeth may nat make no comparisoun
Vn to youre loue and whan this Markys say
The constance of his wyf he caste adoun
Hise eyen two and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre al this array
And forth he goth with drery contenance
But to his herte it was ful gret plesance
This vggly XXgeant in the same wyse
That he hir doghter caughte right so he
Or worse if men worse kan deuyse
Hath hent hir sone that ful was of beautee
And euere in oon so pacient was she
That she no cheere made of heuynesse
But kiste hir sone and after gan it blesse
Saue this she prayde hym that if he myghte
Hir litel sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to sighte
Fro foweles and fro bestes hem to saue
But she noon answere of hym myghte haue
He wente his wey as hym no thyng roghte
But to Boloigne he tendrely it broghte
This Markys wondreth euer lenger the moore
Vp on hir pacience and if that he
Ne hadde soothly knowen ther bifoore
That perfitly hir children loued she
He wolde haue wend that of som subtiltee
And of malice or of cruel corage
That she hadde suffred this with sad visage
But wel he knew that next hym self certayn
She loued hir children best in euery wise
But now of wommen wolde I asken fayn
If thise assayes myghte nat suffise
What koude a sturdy housbond moore deuyse
To proue hir wifhod and hir stedfastnesse
And he contynuynge euere in sturdynesse
But ther ben folk of swich condicioun
That whan they haue a certeyn purpos take
And so wilful suche assayes to make
They kan nat stynte of hir entencioun
But right as they were bounden to that stake
They wol nat of that firste purpos slake
Right so this Markys fulliche hath purposed
To tempte his wyf as he was first disposed
He wayteth if by word or contenance
That she to hym was chaunged of corage
But neuere koude he fynde variance
She was ay oon in herte and in visage
And ay the ferther that she was of age
The moore trewe if that it were possible
She was to hym in loue and moore penyble
For which it semed thus that of hem two
Ther nas but o wyl for as Walter leste
The same lust was hir plesance also
And god be thanked al fyl for the beste
She shewed wel for no worldly vnreste
A wif as of hir self no thyng ne sholde
Wille in effect but as hir housbond wolde
The sclaundre of Walter ofte and wyde spradde
That of a cruel herte he wikkedly
For he a poure womman wedded hadde
Hath mordred bothe his children pryuely
Swich murmur was among hem comunly
No wonder is for to the peples ere
Ther cam no word but that they mordred were
For which wher as his peple ther bifore
Hadde loued hym wel the sclaundre of his diffame
Made hem that they hym hated therfore
To ben a mordrer is an hateful name
But natheles for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel purpos nolde stente
To tempte his wyf was set al his entente
Whan that this doghter xij yer was of age
He to the court of Rome in subtil wise
Enformed of his wil sente his message
Comaundynge hem swiche bulles to deuyse
As to his cruel purpos may suffise
In this maner and in this same gyse
How that the pope as for his peples reste
Bad hym to wedde another if hym leste
I seye he bad they sholde contrefete
The popes bulles makyng mencioun
That he hath leue his firste wyf to lete
As by the popes dispensacioun
To stynte rancour and dissencioun
Bitwix his peple and hym thus seyde the bulle
The which they han publissed at the fulle
The rude peple as it no wonder is
Wenden ful wel that it hadde ben right so
But whan thise tidynges cam to Grisildis
I deme that hir herte was ful wo
But she ylike sad for euere mo
Disposed was this humble creature
Thaduersitee of Fortune al tendure
Abidynge euere his lust and his plesance
To whom that she was yeuen herte and al
As to hir verray worldly suffisance
But shortly if this storie I tellen shal
This Markys writen hath in special
A lettre in which he sheweth his entente
And secrely he to Boloigne it sente
To the Erl of Pavyk which that hadde tho
Wedded his suster prayde he specially
To bryngen hom agayn his children two
In honurable estat al openly
With all his hert ful affectuously
But o thyng he hym prayde outrely
With all his herte ful affectuously
That he to no wight thgh men wolde enquere
Sholde nat tellen whos children that they were
But seye the mayden sholde ywedded be
Vn to the Markys of Saluce anon
And as this Erl was prayd so dide he
For at day set he on his wey is gon
And forth he rod / ful fast a noon
Toward Saluce and lordes many oon
Toward Saluce / this Mayde for to gyde
In riche array this mayden for to gyde
Hir yonge brother ridyng hir bisyde
Arrayed was toward hir mariage
This fresshe mayde ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother which that seuen yeer was of age
Arrayed eek ful fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse and with glad cheere
Toward Saluces shapyng hir iourney
Fro day to day they ryden in hir wey

l.hi: Explicit quarta pars

div.l: Incipit pars quinta
Among al this after his wikke vsage
Incipit pars qᵃnta et Vltima
This Markys yet his wif to tempte moore
To the outreste preue of hir corage
Fully to han experience and loore
If that she were as stedefast as bifore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystously hath seyd hir this sentence
Certes Grisilde I hadde ynogh plesance
To han yow to my wyf for your goodnesse
As for youre trouthe and for your obeysance
Noght for your lynage ne for your richesse
But now knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in gret lordshipe if I wel auyse
Ther is gret seruitute in sondry wyse
I may nat do as euery Plowman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
Another wyf and cryen day by day
And eek the pope rancour for to slake
Consenteth it that dar I vndertake
And trewely thus muche I wol yow seye
My newe wif is comynge by the weye
Be strong of herte and voyde anon hir place
And thilke dower that ye broghten me
Tak it agayn I graunte it of my grace
Retourneth to youre fadres hous quod he
No man may alwey han prosperitee
With euene herte I rede yow tendure
The strook of Fortune or of auenture
And she agayn answerde in pacience
My lord quod she I woot and wiste alway
How that bitwixen youre magnificence
And my pouerte no wight kan ne may
Maken comparisoun it is no nay
I ne heeld me neuere digne in no manere
To be your wyf no ; ne youre chambrere
And in this hous ther ye me lady made
The heighe god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neuere heeld me lady ne maistresse
But humble seruant to youre worthynesse
And euere shal whil that my lyf may dure
Abouen euery worldly creature
That ye so longe of youre benygnytee
Han holden me in honour and nobleye
Where as I was noght worthy for to be
That thonke I god and yow to whom I preye
Foryelde it yow ther is namoore to seye
Vn to my fader gladly wol I wende
And with hym dwelle vn to my lyues ende
Ther I was fostred of a child ful smal
Til I be deed my lyf ther wol I lede
A wydewe clene in body herte and al
For sith I yaf to yow my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wyf it is no drede
God shilde swich a lordes wyf to take
Another man to housbond or to make
And of youre newe wyf god of his grace
So graunte yow wele and prosperitee
For I wol gladly yelden hir my place
In which that I was blisful wont to be
For sith it liketh yow my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertes reste
That I shal goon I wol goon whan yow leste
But ther as ye me profre swich dowaire
As I first broghte it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no thyng faire
The whiche to me were hard now for to fynde
O goode god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by your speche and your visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
But sooth is seyd algate I fynde it trewe
For in effect it proued is on me
Loue is noght old as whan that it is newe
But certes lord for noon aduersitee
To dyen in this cas it shal nat be
That euere in word or werk I shal repente
That I yow yaf myn herte in hool entente
My lord ye woot that in my fadres place
Ye dide me strepe out of my poure wede
And richely me cladden of youre grace
To yow broghte I noght ellis out of drede
But feith and nakednesse and maydenhede
And here agayn my clothyng I restore
And eek my weddyng ryng for euere moore
The remenant of your Iewels redy be
Inwith your chambre dar I saufly sayn
Naked out of my fadres hous quod she
I cam and naked moot I turne agayn
Al youre plesance wol I folwen fayn
But yet I hope it be nat youre entente
That I smoklees out of your palays wente
Ye koude nat doon so dishoneste a thyng
That thilke wombe in which youre children leye
Sholde biforn the peple in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare wher fore I yow preye
Lat me nat lyk a worm go by the weye
Remembre yow myn owene lord so deere
I was youre wyf thogh I vnworthy weere
Wher fore in gerdou of my maydenhede
Which that I broghte and noght agayn I bere
As voucheth sauf to yeue me to my mede
But swich a smok as I was wont to were
That I ther with may wrye the wombe of here
That was youre wyf and here I take my leeue
Of yow myn owene lord lest I yow greeue
The smok quod he that thow hast on thy bak
Lat it be stille and bere it forth with thee
But wel vnnethes thilke word he spak
But wente his wey for routhe and for pitee
Biforn the folk hir seluen strepeth shee
And in hir smok with heued and feet al bare
Toward hir fader hous forth is she fare
The folk hir folwen wepynge in hir weye
And Fortune ay they cursen as they goon
But she fro wepyng kepte hir eyen dreye
Ne in this tyme word ne spak she noon
Hir fader that this tidynge herde anon
Curseth the day and tyme that nature
Shoop hym to been a lyues creature
For out of doute this olde poure man
Was euere in suspect of hir mariage
For euere he demed sith that it bigan
That whan the lord fulfild hadde his corage
Hym wolde thynke it were a disperage
To wedde oon of so pore alynage
To his estat so lowe for talighte
And voyden hir as soone as euere he myghte
Agayns his doghter hastiliche goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew hir comynge
And with hir olde cote as it myghte be
He couered hire ful sorwefully wepynge
But on hir body myghte he it nat brynge
For rude was the clooth and she moore of age
By dayes fele than at hir mariage
Thus with hir fader for a certein space
Dwelleth this flour of wifly pacience
That neyther by hir wordes ne hir face
Biforn the folk ne eek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir heighe estat no remembrance
Ne hadde she as by hir contenance
No wonder is for in hir grete estat
Hir goost was euere in pleyn humylitee
No tendre mouth noon herte delicat
No pompe no semblant of realtee
But ful of pacient benygnytee
Discreet and pridelees ay honurable
And to hir housbonde euere meke and stable
Men speke of Iob and moost for his hunblenesse
As clerkes whan hem lest konne wel endite
Namely of men but as in soothfastnesse
Thogh clerkes preyse wommen but alite
Ther kan no man in humblesse hym acquite
As wommen kan ne kan be half so trewe
As wommen been but it be falle of newe
¶ . Quinta pars .
Incipit pars Sexta
Fro Boloigne is this Erl of Pavyk come
Of which the fame vp sprong to moore and lesse
And to the peples erys alle and some
Was kouth eek that a newe Markisesse
He with hym broghte in swich pomp and richesse
That neuere was ther seyn with mannes eye
So noble array in al westlumbardye
The Markys which that shoop and knew al this
Er that this Erl was come sente his message
For thilke sely poure Grisildis
And she with humble herte and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thoght in hir corage
Cam at his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reuerently and wysly she hym grette
Grisilde quod he my wyl is outrely
This mayden that shal wedded been to me
Receyued be tomorwe as really
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eek that euery wight in his degree
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruyse
And heigh plesance as I kan best deuyse
I haue no wommen suffisant certayn
The chambres for taraye in ordynance
After my lust and ther fore wolde I fayn
That thyn were al swich manere gouernance
Thow knowest eek of old al my plesance
Though thyn array be badde and yuel biseye
Do thow thy deuoir at the leeste weye
Nat oonly lord that I am glad quod she
To doon youre lust but I desire also
Yow for to serue and plese in my degree
With outen feyntyng and shal euere mo
Ne neuere for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the goost with Inne myn herte stente
To loue yow best with al my trewe entente
And with that word she gan the hous to dighte
And tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to doon al that she myghte
Preyynge the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and shake
And she the mooste seruysable of alle
Hath euery chambre arrayed and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl alighte
That with hym broghte thise noble children tweye
For which the peple ran to seen the sighte
Of hire array so richely biseye
And thanne at erst amonges hem they seye
That Walter was no fool thogh that hym leste
To chaunge his wyf for it was for his beste
For she is fairer as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde and moore tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
And moore plesant for hir heigh lynage
Hir brother eek so fair was of visage
That hem to seen the peple hath caught plesance
Commendynge now the Markys gouernance
O stormy peple vnsad and euere vntrewe
Ay vndiscreet and chaungynge as a vane
Delitynge euere in rumbel that is newe
Here may ye se the peple how newe
For lyk the moone ay wexe ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng deere ynow a Iane
And changeable be right as the mane
Youre doom is fals youre constance yuele preueth
A ful greet fool is he that on yow leueth
Thus seyden sadde folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
For they were glad right for the noueltee
To han a newe lady of hir town
Namoore of this make I now mencioun
But to Grisilde agayn wol I me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir bisynesse
Ful bisy was Grisilde in euery thyng
That to the feste was apertinent
Right noght was she abayst of hir clothyng
Thogh it were rude and somdel eek to rent
But with glad cheere to the yate is she went
With oother folk to greete the Markysesse
And after that dooth forth hir bisynesse
With so glad cheere his gestes she receyueth
And so konnyngly euerich in his degree
That no defaute no man aparceyueth
But ay they wondren what she myghte be
That in so poure array was for to se
And koude swich honour and reuerence
And worthily they preysen hir prudence
In al this mene while she ne stente
This mayde and eek hir brother to commende
With al hir herte in ful benygne entente
So wel that no man koude hir prys amende
But at the laste whan that thise lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle
Grisilde quod he as it were in his pley
How liketh thee my wyf and hir beautee
Right wel quod she my lord for in good fey
A fairer saw I neuere noon than she
I prey to god yeue hire prosperritee
And so hope I that he wol to yow sende
Plesance ynogh vn to youre lyues ende
O thyng biseke I yow and warne also
That ye ne prike with no tormentynge
This tendre mayden as ye han do mo
For she is fostred in hir norissynge
Moore tendrely and to my supposynge
She koude nat aduersitee endure
As koude a poure fostred creature
And whan this Walter saw hir pacience
Hir glad cheere and no malice at al
And he so ofte had doon to hir offence
And she ay sad and constant as a wal
Continuynge euere hir Innocence ouer al vbique
With pacience Grisild he quiteth
This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
To rewen vp on hir wifly stedfastnesse
This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
Be now namoore agast ne yuele apayed
I haue thy feith and thy benygnytee
Mankynde which that he wroght
As wel as euere womman was assayed
In greet estat and poureliche arrayed
Now knowe I deere wyf thy stedfastnesse
And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
And she for wonder took of it no keep
She herde nat what thyng he to hir seyde
She ferde as she hadde stirt out of a sleep
Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thow art my wyf noon oother I haue
Ne neuere hadde as god my soule saue
This is thy doghter which thow hast supposed
To be my wyf that oother feithfully
Shal be myn heir as I haue ay supposed
Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
At Boloigne haue I kept hem priuely
Tak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye
That thow hast lorn noon of thy children tweye
And folk that oother weys han seyd of me
I warne hem wel that I haue doon this dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But for tassaye in thee thy wommanhede
And nat to sleen my children god forbede
But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
Til I thy purpos knewe and al thy wille
Whan she this herde aswowne doun she falleth
For pitous ioye and after hir swownynge
She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
And in hir armes pitously wepynge
Embraceth hem and tendrely kissynge
Ful lyk a moder with hir salte terys
She batheth bothe hir visage and hir herys
O which a pitous thyng it was to se
O such a pitous thing it was to see
Hir swownyng and hir humble voys to heere
Grant mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
That ye han saued me my children deere
Now rekke I neuere to been ded right heere
Sith I stonde in your loue and in youre grace
No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
O tendre o deere o yonge children myne
Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
That cruel houndes or som foul vermyne
Hadde eten yow but god of his mercy
And youre benygne fader tendrely
Hath doon yow kept and in that same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
And in hir swogh so sadly holdeth she
Hir children two whan she gan hem tembrace
That with greet sleghte and greet difficultee
The children from hir arm they gonne arace
O many a teer o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem that stoden hir bisyde
Vnnethe aboute hir myghte they abyde
Walter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
She riseth vp abaysed from hir traunce
And euery wight hir ioye and feste maketh
Til she hath caught agayn hir contenaunce
Walter hir dooth so feithfully plesaunce
That it was deyntee for to seen the cheere
Bitwix hem two now they ben met yfeere
Thise ladies whan that they hir tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chambre goon
And strepen hir out of hir rude aray
And in a clooth of gold that brighte shoon
With a coroune of many a riche stoon
Vp on hir hed they in to halle hir broghte
And ther she was honured as hir oghte
Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For euery man and womman dooth his myght
This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
Til on the welkne shoon the sterres lyght
For moore solempne in euery mannes syght
This feste was and gretter of costage
Than was the reuel of hir mariage
Ful many a yeer in heigh prosperitee
Lyuen thise two in concord and in reste
And richely his doghter maried he
Vn to a lord oon of the worthyeste
Of al Ytaille and thanne in pees and reste
His wyues fader and his court he kepeth
Til that the soule out of his body crepeth
His sone succedeth in his heritage
In reste and pees after his fader day
And fortunat was eek his mariage
Al putte he nat his wyf in gret assay
This world is nat so strong it is no nay
As it hath been in olde tymes yore
And herkneth what this Auctour seith therfore
This storie is seyd nat for that wyues sholde
Folwen Grisilde as in humylitee
For it were inpor table thogh they wolde
But for that euery wight in his degree
Sholde be constant in aduersitee
As was Grisilde therfore Petrak writeth
This storie which he with heigh stile enditeth
For sith a womman was so pacient
Vn to a mortal man wel moore vs oghte
Receyuen al in gree that god vs sent
For gret skile is he preue that he wroghte
But he ne tempteth no man that he boghte
As seith Seint Iame if ye his pistel rede
He preueth folk al day it is no drede
And suffreth vs as for oure excercise
With sharpe scourges of aduersitee
Ful ofte to be bete in sondry wise
Nat for to knowe oure wyl for certes he
Er we were born knew al oure freletee
And for oure beste is al his gouernance
Lat vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffrance
But o word lordynges herkneth er I go
It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
In al a town Grisildis thre or two
For if that they were put to swiche assayes
The gold of hem hath now so badde alayes
With bras that thogh the coigne be fair at eye
It wolde rather breste atwo than plye
For which heere for the wyues loue of Bathe
Whos lyf and al hir secte god mayntene
In heigh maistrie or ellis were it scathe
I wol with lusty herte fressh and grene
Seye yow a song to glade yow I wene
And lat vs stynte of ernestful matere
Herkneth my song that seith in this manere

l.hi: Here is ended the tale of the clerk of Oxenford

div.l: ¶ lenuoye de chaucer
Griselde is dede and eke hir pacience
And both atones buryed in ytalie
For whiche I crie in open audience /
No wedded man be hardy to. assail
His wiffes pacience in truste to fynde
Griseldes for in certeyn he schal faille
¶ O noble wiffes ful of hiegh prudence
Let non humilite ȝour tonge naylle
Ne lat no clerke haue cause or diligence
To write of ȝowe a storie of suche maruayl
As of Griseldꝭes paciente and kynde
Leste chicheuage ȝowe swelowe in hir entrail
¶ Folowith ekko þat holdeth no silence
But eủer/re answereth at þe countr tail
Beth not be daffed for ȝour Innocence
But scharply take on ȝowe þe gouernaille
Enprynteth wel þis lessoıı̄un in ȝour mynde
For commıı̄un ꝓprofite sith it may a vail
¶ Ne drede hem noȝt doth hem no reủer/reence
For þof þine husbonde araied be in mayl
The arwes of þi crabbed Eloquence
Shal perse his breste and eke his aduentail
In Ialousie I rede eke þou hym bynde
And þat þou make hym couche as doith a quail
¶ If þou be fair þer folke bene in psencs
Shewe þou þi visage and þine apparaille
Ȝiff þou be foule be fr of þi despense
To gete þe frendes ay do þi trauail
Be ay of cher als liȝht as lefe on lynde
And lete hym car and wepe and wrynge and waille
¶ Ȝe Archewyffes stondith at ȝour defense
Seth ȝe be stronge as is a grete camail
Ne suffreth not þat man do ȝowe offence
And sclender wyffes feble as in bataille
Beth egr as a tigr ȝonde in ynde
Ay clappith as a Mil I ȝowe conseil
¶ Explicit fabula Griseldia
Here beginneth þe prologe of þe Frankeleyn:
Eye god mercy seid our oste þoo
Nowe suche a wyffe I pray god kepe me froo /
Lo suche sleighte / and subtilitees
As women bene for and as besy as bees .
Beth þei vs foly men for to disseyue .
And from a sothe euer willeth weyue
By þis marchaundes tale it ꝓproueth wele
But douteles als trewe as eủer/re was eny stele
I haf a wyff þof sche poủer/re be
