That ȝe han said is riȝht ynogh y wys ¶þ
And michel more / for litell heuynesse
Is riȝht ynogh to mychell folke as I gesse
I seye for me it is a grete disese
Wher as men han bene in grete welth and ese
To heren of hir sodeyn falle allas
And þe contrarie ioye and grete solas
And whan a man hath bene in por astate
And clymbeth up and wexeth fortunate
And þer abideth in prosperite
Suche thyng is gladsom / as it thynketh me
And þof suche thynge wer goodly for to tell
Ȝa qd our ooste be seynt Poules bell
Ȝe seye riȝht soth þis monke he clappeth lowde
He spak howe fortune couered with a clowde
I not neủer/re what and also of atreide
Riȝt nowe ȝe herde and ꝑper/parde no remedie
It is for to bewaill and 9pleyn
That is to don and als it is a peyn
As ȝe han seide to her of heuynesse
Sir monke no mor of þis so god ȝowe blisse
Ȝour tales annoieth all þis companye
Suche talkynge is not worth a butterflye
For þ̉er/rein is no desporte ne game
Wher fore sir monke daun piers be ȝour name
I pray ȝowe hertly tell us somwhat ells
For siker ner þe clynkynge of ȝour belles
That on ȝour bridell hongeth on eủer/rey side
By heuen kynge þat for us all dyede
I schall for þis falle doun for slepe
Al þof þe slogh had neủer/re ben so depe
Than had ȝour tale be tolde in vayn
For certenly as þise clerkis seyne
Wher as a man may haf none audience
It helpeth noȝt to tellen his sentence
And wele þe substaunce is in me
If ony thynge schall wele reported be
Sir say somwhat of huntynge I ȝowe praye
Nay qd þe monke I haf no luste pleye
Nowe lete a noþ̉er/re tell as I haf tolde
Than spake our ooste with rude speche and bolde
And seide vn to þe nonnes preste onon
Come ner sir preste com hider ʆser/sir Iohn
Tell us suche thynges as may our hertes gladde
Be mery þof þou ride opon a iade .
That þof þine horse be foule or lene
Iff he will ʆser/sirue þᵉ rekke þᵉ noȝht a bene þ
Looke þat þine herte be mery eủer/re moo
Ȝis oste qd he so mot I ride or goo
But I be mery I wys I will be blamed
And riȝht onon he hath his tale attamed
And þus he seide to us euỷer/rechon
This swete preste þis good man ʆser/sir Ione

hi.hi: ¶ Here endith þe ꝓprologe ⁊and here begynneth þe tale .

div.l: A por wydowe som dele stope in age
Was whilom dwellynge in an narowe cotage
Besides a groue stondynge in a dale
This wydowe of whiche I told yowe my tale
Sethens þilke day þat sche was laste a wyffe
In paciens ladde a full simple lyffe
For litill was hir catell and hir rente
By husbondrye as of suche þat god hir sente
She fonde her selfe and eke hir doughtren twoo
Thr large sowes sche hadde and no moo
Thr kyen and eke a schepe þat hiȝht malle
Full soty was hir bowr and eke hir halle
In whiche sche ete mony a sklender mele
Of poynant sause her neded neủer/re a dele
No deynte morsell passed hir throte
Hir diete was acordant to hir cote
Replecioıı̄un ne made hir neủer/re seke
A tepre diete was al hire phisike
And esise and herte suffisaunce
The ȝoute letteth hir no thynge to daunce
Ne poplexie ne schent not hir hede
No wyne dranke sche nouther white ne rede
Her borde was serued moste with white and blakke
Milke and brounbrede in whiche sche fonde no lakke
Seynde bakoıı̄un and somtyme an eye or tweye
For sche was as it wer þe maner of a deye
A gardyn sche hadde enclosed all aboute
With stikkes and a drye diche with oute
In whiche sche hadde a coke þat hiȝht Chantcler
In all þe londe of crowynge was his per
His voys was merier þan þe merye orgon
On messe daies þat in chirche gone
Wel sikerer was þe crowynge in his logge
Then is a clokke or an Abbeye orlogge
By natur he knewe iche ascencoıı̄un
Of equinoxiall of þilke toun
For when degrees xv. wer descended þȝhþ
div.fw: Then knewe he þat it myȝht
div.l: Then knewe he þat it myȝht not bene amendede
His combe was redder þen þe fyne corall
And batelid as it wer a castell wall
I like azur wer his legges and his tone
His bille was blak and as þe gete it schone
His naylles whitter þan þe lily flour
And ylyke burnysshed golde was his colour
This gentill Coke hadde in his gouernaunce
Seuen hennes for to don his plesaunce
Whiche weren his sustres and his ꝑper/paramours
And wonder y like to hym as of coloures
Off whiche þe fayrest hewed vndir þe throte
Was cleped fair damysell ꝑper/partilote
Curtas sche was discrete and debonair
And companable and bar hir selfe so fair
Sethyns þilke day þat sche was seuen nyȝht olde
That trewly sche hathe þe herte in holde
Off Chauntecler loken in eủer/rey lith
He loued hir so þat wele was hym þ̉er/re wyth
But suche a Ioye as it was to her hem synge
And so befell þat in þe dawnynge .
As Chauntecler amonges his wyffes alle
Satte on his ꝑper/parche þat was in þe hall
And nexte hym satte þis fair ꝑper/partelotte
This Chauntecler gāmn gronen in his throte
As a man þat is in dreme drecched sor
And when þat ꝑper/partelot þus herde hym rore
She was a gast and seide hertis der
What eylith ȝowe to grone in þis manere
Ye ben a verrey sleper ffy for schame
And he answered and saide þus madame
I pray ȝowe þat ȝe take it not a greefe
By god me mette þat I was in suche myschiefe
Riȝht nowe þat ȝit myn herte is sor a fryȝht
Nowe god qd he my sweuen rede a riȝht
And kepe my body oute of foule prisoun
Me mette þat I romede up and doun
With in oure ȝerde wher as I sagh a beste
Was like an hounde and wolde haf made a reste
Vpon my body and wolde haf had me dede
His colour was be twix white and rede
And tipped was his taille and both his eres
With blake vnlike þe remenᵃıı̄unt of his heeres
His snowte small with glowynge eyen tweye
Yette of his looke for feer almooste I dye
This caused me my gronynge doutelesse
A voy qd sche. fy on ȝowe hertelesse ¶
Allas ꝙquod sche ffor by þat god aboue
Nowe haue ȝe loste myn herte and my loue
I con not loue a cowarde be my feyth.
For certes what so eny woman seith
We all desiren ȝiff it myȝht be
To hauen husbondes hardy wyse and free
And secree ne no negarde ne no foole
Ne hym þat is a gast of eủer/rey toole
Ne none avontr be þat godde aboue
Howe dorste ȝe seyn for schame vn to ȝoᵘur loue
That eny thynge myȝht make ȝowe aferde
Haue ȝe no mannys herte and han a berde
Allas and kon ȝe ben agaste of sweıı̄unens
No thynge god wote but vanite in sweuen . is
Sweuens engendren of replexiouns
And ofte of fume and of complexiouns
When humors bene to habundant in a wyȝht
Certes þis dreme whiche ȝe haf harde to nyȝht
Comyth of þe grete suꝑper/parfluite
Of ȝour rede colour parde
Whiche causeth folke to dreme hir dremes
Of arwes and of fuyres with rede lemes
Of rede bestis þat wollen hem bite
Of conteke and of whelpes grete and lite
Riȝht as þe humore malencolye
Cawsith mony a man in slepe for to crye
For fer of beres and bulles blake
Or ells blake deuylls woll hem take
Of other humours couth I tell . also
That wyrken mony a man in slepe full woo
But I woll passe as liȝhtly as I kan
Loo Catoıı̄un whiche þat was so wise a man
Seide he not þus ne do no force of dremes
Nou sir ꝙquod sche when we fle fro þe bemes
For goddis luff as takith som laxatiue
Vpon ꝑper/parill of my soule and of my lyffe
I counseill ȝowe þe beste I woll not lye
That both of colour and malencolye
Ȝe purge ȝowe and for ȝe schull not tarie
Thogh þat in þis town nys none Apothecarie
I schall my selfe to herbes techen ȝowe
That schall be ȝour hele and ȝour prowe
And in þe gardyn two herbes schall I fynde
The whiche han of her ꝓpropirte be kynde
To purchen ȝowe be nethe and eke aboue
For ȝetith not þis for goddis own loue . ¶
Ye ben full coleryke of complexioıı̄un
Where þe sonne in his ascencioun
Ne fynde ȝowe replete of ȝour humours hote
And if it do I dar wele lay a grote
That ȝe schull haue a fevr terciane
Or an agu þat may be ȝour bane
A day or two ȝe schull haf digestyues
Or wormes or ȝe take ȝour laxatiues
Of laureal centaure and of fumytere
Or ells of ellebor þat growith þere
Of Catapuce or of gaytes buryes
Of herbe yne growynge in our ȝerde þ̉er/re merye is
Pyk hem up riȝht as þei growe ande ete hem in
Be mery husbonde for ȝour fadres kynne
Dredith no dreme I con saye to ȝowe no mor
Madame qd he gramercy of ȝour lore
But nathelesse as touchyng daun catoıı̄un
That hath of wysdom suche grete renoun
By god men may in olde bokes rede
One of þe grettest auctory oute of drede
Of mony a man mor of auctorite
Than eủer/re Catoıı̄un was so mot I thee
That all þe reủer/rese seyne of þis sentence
And hauen wele founden be exꝑper/parience
That dremes ben significacioıı̄uns
Als wele of Ioye as of tribulacoıı̄uns
That folke enduren in þis liffe psente
Ther nedith not to make of þis non argumente
The verrey preue schewith it in dede
One of þe grettest auctour oute of drede
Sēmīmth þus þat whilom two felowes wente
On pilgⁱmage in full goode entente
And happed so þei comen in to a towne
Wher as þer was suche congregacioıı̄un
Of peple and eke of streyte herbergage
That þei fonde as myche as a cotage
In whiche þei both ne myȝht y logged be
Wherfore þei mosten of necessite
As for þat nyȝht deꝑper/parten of companye
And iche of hem goth in to his ostelerye
And toke his loggynge as it wolde fall
That one of hem was logged in a stall
Fer in a ȝerde with oxen of þe . plogh
That oþ̉er/re man was logged wele ynogh
As was his auentur or his fortune
That us goủer/reneth all as in comune . ¶þ
And so by fell longe ar it wer daye
Þis man mette in his bedde where as he laye
Howe þat his felowe gan on hym calle
And seide allas for in an oxe stalle
This nyȝht schall I be murdred ther I lye
Nowe helpe me dere brother or I dye
In alle haste come to me he saide
This man oute of his slepe for fer he brayde
But when þat he was wakened oute of his slepe
He turnyth hym and toke of þis no kepe .
Hym thoȝht his dreme was not but a vanite
Thus twies in his slepynge dremed he
And at þe thridde tyme ȝit his felowe
Come as he thouȝht I am nowe y slawe
Beholde my blody woundes depe and wyde
Arise up . erly in þe morowe tyde
And at þe westgate of þe towne qd he
A carte full of donge þ̉er/re schalt you see
In whiche his body is hidde full priuely
Do þilke carte aresten boldly
My golde causede my mordr sothe to seyn
And tolde hym eủer/rey poynte howe he was slayn
With a full pytous face pale of hewe
And truste wele his dreme he fonde full trewe
For on þe morne als sone as it was daye
To his felowes in . he toke þe weye
And when he come to þis oxe stalle
Aft̉er/re his felowe he began to calle
The ostiler answered hym onon
And seide sir ȝour felowe is y gone
Als sone as day he wente oute of þe towne
This man gan fall in grete suspicioıı̄un
Remembrynge on his dremes þat he mette
And forth he goith no leng wolde he lette
Vn to þe weste gate of þe toune and fonde
A donge carte as he wente to dong þe londe
That was araied in þe same wyse
As ȝe han herde þe dede man devise
And with an hardy herte he gan to crye
Vencheance and iustice of þis felonye
My felowe murdrede is þⁱs same nyȝht
And in þis carte he lieth gapyng up riȝht
The dede man þat murdrede was al newe
O blysfull god þat arte so iuste and trewe
Lo howe þat þou bewreyest murdr al weye
Murdr woll oute þat see we day be daye þ
Mordr is so horrible and so abhominable
To god þat is so iuste and resonable
That he ne wolde it suffre not to heled be
Theigh it abide a ȝer or twoo or three
Murdr woll oute þis is my conclusioıı̄un
And riȝht onon ministres of þe toune
Hath hente þe Carter and sor hym pynede
And eke þe Osteler so fastly was engynede
That þei beknewe her wykkednes onone
And weren honged by þe nekke bone
Her may men se þat dremes bene to drede
And certes in þe same booke y rede
Riȝht in þe nexte chapitr I rede of þis
I gabbe not so haf I Ioye or blisse .
Two men þat wolden haf passed þe see
For certeyn causes in to a feir cuntr
If þat þe wynde ne hadde bene contrarye
That made hem in a Cite for to tarie
That stode full mery opon an hauen side
But on a day a ȝeinste þe euen tide
The wynde gan chonge and blowe riȝht as he luste
Iolyff and gladde þei wenten vn to reste
And kasten hem full erly for to saile
But herken howe o man fell in grete ꝑper/parill
The tone of hem in slepynge as he laye
Hym mette a wonder a wonder dreme aȝeinste þe daye
Hym thouȝht a man stode be his beddys side
And hym cōmmanded þat he schuld abyde
And seide hym þus if þou to morowen wende
Thow schalt be dreynte my tale is at an ende
He woke and tolde his felowe what he mette
And praied hym his viage for to lette
And for þat day he praied hym to abide
His felowe þat laye be his beddis syde
Gan for to lawgh and skorned full faste
No dreeme qd he may myn herte a gaste
That I woll lete for to do my thynges
I sate not a strawe by dremynges
For sweuens bene but vanites and iapes
Men dreme al weye of owles ande of Apes
And of mony a mase þer with alle
Men dremēm of thynge þat neủer/re was ne schall
But sithen I see þou wilte her abide
And þus forslewthen wilfully þi tyde
God wote it reweth me and haf good daye
And þus he toke his leue and wente his waye . ¶þ
And er þat he hadde halfe his course assailled
Note I not why ne what myschance it ayled
But casuelly þe schippes bottome rente
And schippe and man vnder þe wat̉er/re wente
In siȝht of oþ̉er/re schippes hym be side
That with hym sailled at þe same tyde
And þ̉er/refor he seide ꝑper/partelote so dere
By suche olde ensample mayst þou ler
That no man schulde be to rechelesse
Of dremes for I saye þe doutelesse
That mony a dreme full sore is for to drede
Loo in þe lyffe of seynte kenelme I rede
That was kenulphes son þe noble kynge
Off Mertenrike howe kenelme mete a thynge
A litill er he was mordrede on a daye
His murdr in his avision he seye
His norice hym expowned euỷer/re dele
His sweuen and bad hym for to kepe hym wele
For treson but he was vij ȝer olde
And þ̉er/re for litill tale hath he tolde
Of eny dreme so holy was his herte
By god I had leủer/re þan my scherte
That ȝe had harde his legende as haff I .
Dame ꝑper/partelotte I seye ȝowe trewly .
Maccobeus þat writte þe avisioun
In Affrike of þe worthy Cyprioun
Affermeth dremes and seith þᵗat þei bene
Warnynge of thynges þat men aft̉er/re seen
And forthermor I pᵃye ȝowe lokith wele
The olde testament of daniele
Ȝiff he helde dremes of eny vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph and ȝe schullen see .
Whedir dremes bene somtyme I seye not alle
Warnynge of thynges þat schull aft̉er/re falle
Looke eke of egypte þe kynge daun pharao .
His baker and his botiler also
Wher þei ne felte non effecte in dremes
Who so woll seche þe acte of sundry remes
May reden of dremes mony a wonder thynge
Loo cresus whiche þat was of lide kynge
Mette he not þat he satte opon a tree
Whiche signified þat he schuld an honged be
Loo her of dromacha ectours wyffe
That day þat Ectour schuld lete his lyffe
She dremed on þe same nyȝht be forne
Howe þat þe lyffe of ectour schulde be lorne . þ
Yiff þilke daye he wente in to bataille
She warnyd hym but it myȝht not availl
He wente for to fyȝhten neủer/re þe lesse
But he was slayn of Achilles
But þilke tale is al to longe to tell
And eke it is nygh day I may not dwell
Shortly I seye as for conclusioun
That I schall haf of þis a visioun
Of aduersites and I seye forthermor
That I ne will telle of laxatiues no store
For þei bene venynous I wote riȝht wele
I hem defye I loue hem neủer/re a dele
Now lete us speke of myrthe and stynte all þis
Madame ꝑper/partelote so haf I blysse
Off oo thynge god hath sente me large gᵃce
For when I see þe beaute of ȝour face
Ȝe bene so skarlete rede a boute ȝour eyen
It makith all my drede for to dyen
For also siker as in principio

l.hi: Mulier est hominus confusio

div.l: Madame þe sentence of þis latyn is
Woman is mannys Ioye and his blisse
For when I fele on nyȝht ȝour softe syde
Al be it þat I may not on ȝowe ride
For þat our ꝑper/parche is made so narowe allas
I am so full of Ioye and solace
That I desir both sweuen and dreme
And with þat worde I fliegh doune fro þe beme .
For it was day and eke his hennes alle
And with a chukke he gan hem for to calle
For he hadde founde a corne laye in þe ȝerde
Reall he was no mor a ferde
He fethered ꝑper/partelot . xx . tyme
And dradde als ofte er it wer pⁱrime
He lokith as it wer a grym lyoun
And on his toos he romed up and doun
Hym deygned not to sette his fete on grounde
Ay chukkede as when he hadde a corne y founde
And to hym þan ranne his wyfes all
Thus royall as a prince in his halle
Leue I þis Chauntecler in þis pastur
And aft̉er/re woll I tell of his auentur
When þe month þe whiche þe worde began
That hiȝht marche when god firste made man
Was plete and passede wele also
Sethen marche began xxx dayes and twoo. ¶þ
Byfell þat Chauntecler in his pride
His seuen wyffes welken hym beside
Caste up his eighen to þe bryȝht son .
That in þe signe of taurus was ronne
Twenty degrees and one and sumwhat mor
He knewe be kynde ande by none other lore .
That it was prime he crewe with blesfull steven
The sonne he seide is clomben vp on heuen
Fourty degrees and more and one of wys
Madame ꝑper/partelote my wordliche blisse
Herken howe þise blesfull briddes synge
And se þe fressh floures howe þei spⁱringe .
Full is myn herte of reuell and solace
But sothenly hym fell a sorofull caase
Foreủer/re þe latter ende of ioye is sone a goo
And cmnly ofte tyme it fallith soo .
And if arthour couthe fair endite
He in cronikle myȝht sauely wrytte
As for a souereyn notabilite
Nowe eủer/rey wyse man herken me
This storye is als trewe I vndirtake
As is þe booke of launcelot de lake
That wōmmen helde in full grete reuerence
Nowe woll I turne a ȝeyn to my sentence
A col fox full of sleight and iniquite
That in þe grove had wonned ȝeres thr̉er/re
Be hiȝhg ymaginacioıı̄un a forne caste
The same nyȝht þurgh oute þe hogges braste
In to þe ȝerde þer chaunteclere þe fair
Was wonte and eke his wyffes to repair
And in a bedde of wortes still he laye .
Til it was passed vndron of þe daye
Waytynge his tyme on chauntecler to fall
As gladly done þis homicides all
That in a wayte ligge to murther men
O fals mourdrour roukynge in þi denne
O newe skariot and newe genylon
Fals dissimilour o greke synion
That broȝht troye all vtterly to sorowe
O chauntecler a cursed be þat morowe
That þou in to þe ȝerde fliegh fro þe bemes
Thou wer full wele y werned by þe dremes
That ilk day was ꝑper/parlious to þe
Bot þat þat god a forwote mote nedys be
Han in myn house y been to ȝowe grete ese .
And certes sir riȝht fayne wolde I ȝowe pleess þ
But for men spekith of synginge I woll seye
So mot I broke myn eyen tweye
Safe ȝe I ne harde neủer/re man synge
As did ȝour fader in þe mornynge
Certis it was of herte all þat he songe
And for to make his voys þe more stronge
He wolde so peyn hym þat with both his eyen
He moste wynke so loude he did cryen
And stonden on his tiptoos þ̉er/re with all
And stretche forth his nekke longe and small
And eke he was of suche discrecioıı̄un
That þer nas no man in no regioun
That hym in songe or wysdom myȝht passe
I haf wele rede Daun Burnell þer as
Amonge his verse þer was a coke
For a prestis son ȝaf hym a knokke
O pon his legge whils he was ȝonge and nyce
He made hym for to lese his benefice
But c̉er/reten þ̉er/re is non comꝑper/parisoun
Betwix þe wysdom and discrecioıı̄un
Of ȝour fader and of his subtilite
Nowe syngith sir for seynte charitee
Lat see con ȝe ȝour fader countrfete
This Chauntecler his wen9 gan to bete

div.l: (base) ¶ The prologe / of the Chanouns Yemannes tale ~
(base) ¶ hic incipit fabula Canonici
(base) Whan toold was al the lyf / . of Seinte Cecile
(base) Er we hadde riden / fully fyue Mile
(base) At Boghtoun vnder Blee / vs gan atake
(base) A man / that clothed was / in clothes blake
(base) And vnder nethe / he wered a Surplys
(base) His hakeney / which that was al pomely grys
(base) So swatte / that it wonder was to see
(base) It semed / as he had priked Miles three
(base) The hakeney eek / that his yeman rood vpon
(base) So swatte / that vnnethe myghte it gon
(base) Aboute þe peytrel stood þe foom ful hye
(base) He was of foom as flekked as a pye
(base) A Male tweyfoold / vp on his croper lay
(base) It semed / that he caried lite array
(base) Al light for Somer / rood this worthy man
(base) And in myn herte / to wondren I bigan
(base) What that he was / til that I vnderstood
(base) How that his cloke / was sowed to his hood
(base) For which / whan I hadde longe auysed me
(base) I demed hym / som Chanoun for to be
(base) His hat heeng / at his bak / doun by a laas
(base) For he hadde riden / moore than trot or paas
(base) He hadde ay priked / lik as he were wood
(base) A Clote leef / he hadde vnder his hood
(base) For swoot and for to kepe his heed from heete
(base) But it was ioye / for to seen hym swete
(base) His forheed dropped / as a Stillatorie
(base) Were ful of Plantayne / and of Paritorie
(base) And whan that he was come / he gan to crye
(base) God saue quod he / this ioly compaignye
(base) Faste haue I priked quod he / for youre sake
(base) By cause / that I wolde yow atake
(base) To riden / in som myrie compaignye
(base) His yeman eek was ful of curteisye
(base) And seyde sires / now in the morwe tyde
(base) Out of youre hostelrie / I saugh yow ryde
(base) And warned heer / my lord and my souerayn
(base) Which / to ryden with yow / is ful fayn
(base) For his desport he loueth daliaunce
(base) ¶ Freend / for thy warnyng god yeue thee chaunce
(base) Thanne seyde oure hoost. for certein / it wolde seme
(base) Thy lord were wys / and so I may wel deme
(base) He is ful iocunde also / dar I leye
(base) Can he oght telle / a myrie tale or tweye
(base) With which / he glade may this compaignye ;
(base) ¶ Who sire my lord ; ye / ye with outen lye

div.l: (base) He kan of murthe / and eek of Iolitee
(base) Nat but ynough / also sir trusteth me
(base) And ye hym knewe / as wel as do I
(base) Ye wolde wondre / how wel and craftily
(base) He koude werke / and that in sondry wise
(base) He hath take on hym /. many a greet empⁱrise
(base) Which were ful hard / for any that is heere
(base) To brynge aboute / but they of hym it leere
(base) As hoomly / as he rit amonges yow
(base) If ye hym knewe / it wolde be for youre prow
(base) Ye wolde nat forgoon his Aqueyntaunce
(base) For muchel good / I dar leye in balaunce
(base) Al that I haue / in my possessioun
(base) He is a man / of heigh discrecioun
(base) I warne yow wel / he is a passyng man
(base) ¶ Wel quod oure hoost . I pray thee tel me than
(base) Is he a clerk / or noon ; telle what he is
(base) ¶ Nay / he is gretter than a clerk ywis
(base) Seyde this yeman / and in wordes fewe
(base) Hoost of his craft som what I wol yow shewe
(base) ¶ I seye / my lord / kan swich subtilitee
(base) But al his craft. ye may nat wite for me
(base) And somwhat helpe I yet to his wirking
(base) That al this ground / on which we been ridyng
(base) Til that we come / to Caunterbury toun
(base) For al the ground to Caunterbury toun
(base) He koude al clene / turne it vp so doun
(base) And paue it / al of siluer / and of gold
(base) ¶ And whan this yeman / hadde this tale ytold
(base) Vn to oure hoost. he seyde benedicitee
(base) This thyng is wonder mueillous to me
(base) Syn that thy lord / is of so heigh prudence
(base) By cause of which / men sholde hym reuerence
(base) That of his worship / rekketh he so lite
(base) His ouerslop / nys nat worth a myte
(base) As in effect to hym / so moot I go
(base) It is al baudy / and to tore also
(base) Why is thy lord so sluttissh I the preye
(base) And is of power bettre clooth to beye
(base) If that his dede / accorde with thy speche
(base) Telle me that. and that I thee biseche
(base) ¶ Why quod this yeman ; / wherto axe ye me ;
(base) God help me so / for he shal neuere thee
(base) But I wol nat anowe that I seye
(base) And therfore / keep it secree I yow preye
(base) He is to wys / in feith / as I bileeue
(base) That that is ouerdoon / it wol nat preeue

div.l: (base) Aright ; / as clerkes seyn / it is a vice
(base) Wherfore in that I holde hym lewed ⁊and nyce
(base) For whan a man / hath ouer greet a wit
(base) Ful oft hym happeth / to mysusen it
(base) So dooth my lord / and that me greueth soore
(base) God it amende / I kan sey yow namoore
(base) ¶ Ther of no fors / good yeman / quod oure hoost
(base) Syn of the konnyng of thy lord thow woost
(base) Telle how he dooth / I pray thee hertely
(base) Syn that he is / so crafty and so sly
(base) Where dwelle ye / if it to telle be ;
(base) ¶ In the Suburbes / of a toun quod he
(base) Lurkynge in hernes / and in lanes blynde
(base) Where as thise robboᵘurs / and thise theues by kynde
(base) Holden / hir pryuee fereful residence
(base) As they / that dar nat shewen hir presence
(base) So faren we / if I shal seye the sothe
(base) ¶ Now quod oure hoost / . lat me telle to the
(base) Why artow / so discoloured of thy face ;
(base) ¶ Peter quod he / god yeue it harde grace
(base) I am so vsed / in the fyr to blowe
(base) That it hath chaunged my colour I trowe
(base) I am nat wont in no Mirour to prie

(base) To muchel folk / we doon illusioun
(base) And borwe gold / be it a pound or two

(base) Yet is it fals / but ay we han good hope
(base) It for to doon / and after it we grope
(base) But that Science / is so fer vs biforn
(base) We mowen nat al though we hadden sworn
(base) It ouertake / it slit awey so faste
(base) It wole / vs maken beggers atte laste
(base) ¶ Whil this yeman / was thus in his talkyng
(base) This Chanoun drough hym neer ⁊and herde al thyng
(base) Which this yeman spak / for suspecioun
(base) Of mēmnes speche / euere hadde this Chanoun
(base) For Catoun seith / that he that gilty is
(base) Demeth alle thyng. be spoke of hym ywis
(base) That was the cause / he gan so ny / hym drawe
(base) To his yeman / to herknen al his sawe

div.l: (base) And thus he seyde / vn to his yeman tho
(base) Hoold thou thy pees / and spek no wordes mo

(base) ¶ Ye quod oure hoost / telle on what so bityde
(base) Of al his thretyng rekke nat a myte
(base) ¶ In feith quod he / namoore I do but byte
(base) ¶ And whan this Chanoun / saugh it wolde nat bee
(base) But his yeman / wolde telle his pryuetee
(base) He fledde awey / for verray sorwe and shame
(base) ¶ A quod the yeman / heere shal arise game

(base) That feele I wel / what that any man seith
(base) And yet for al my smert and al my grief

(base) Now wolde god / my wit myghte suffise
(base) To tellen / al that longeth / to that Art
(base) And nathelees / yow wol I tellen part
(base) Syn that my lord is goon / I wol nat spare
(base) Swich thyng / as that I knowe / I wol declare
(base) ¶ Heere endeth the prologe of the Chanouns Yemannes tale ~
(base) With this chanoun dwelled haue I seuen ȝeer
(base) And of his science am I neuer the neer
(base) Al that I hadde I haue y lost therby
(base) And god wot so haue many mo than I
(base) Ther I was wont to be right freissch and gay
(base) Of clothing and of good array
(base) Now may I were an hose vpon myn heed
(base) And wher my colour was bothe freissh and reed
(base) Now is it wan and of a ledene hewe
(base) Who so it vseth sore schal he rewe
(base) And of my swynk ȝit blered is myn yȝe
(base) Lo which auauntage it is to multiplye
(base) That slydynge science hath me maad so bare

(base) Of gold that I haue borwed trewely

div.l: (base) That whil I lyue I schal it quite neuere /
(base) Lat euery man be war by me for euere /
(base) What maner man that casteth him therto
(base) If he continue I holde his thrifte y do

(base) Thus was I ones lerned of a clerk
(base) Of that no charge I wol speke of oure werk
(base) Whan we ben there as we schulle exercise
(base) Oure eluysshe craft ; we semen wonder wise
(base) Oure termes ben so clergeal and so queynte
(base) I blowe the fuyr til that myn herte feynte
(base) What scholde I telle eche proporcioun
(base) Of thinges whiche that we worchen vppon
(base) As on fyue or sixe vnces may wel be
(base) Of siluer ore of som other quantite
(base) And besye me to telle ȝou the names

(base) That in to poudre grounden ben ful smal
(base) And in an erthen pot how that put is al

div.l: (base) And eek thyne vrynals / and thy Iurdones
(base) Thyn Ypocras / and eek thy galyones
(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan
(base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme

(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle

(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake

(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
(base) ¶ Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal here
(base) But in the cuppe wol I me bithinke
(base) ¶ I graunte ywis quod he / but I moot thynke
(base) Vpon som honeste thyng whil that I drynke

(base) Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
And here begynneth þe tale
Lordynges qd he in chirche when I pche
I peyne me to haue an hauten speche
I rynge it oute als rounde as goith a bell
For I kan all by rote þat I tell
My teme is alwey one and eủer/re was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Firste I ꝓprononce whens þat I com
And then my bulles I schewe all and som
Our liege lorde seele on my patente
That schewe I firste my body to warente
That no man be so bolde preste ne clerke
Me to distourble of Cristꝭes holy werke
And aft̉er/re þat tell I forth my tales
Bulles of Popes and of Cardinales
Of patriarkes and bysshops I schewe
And in latyn I speke wordes a fewe
To saue with my pdicacioıı̄un
And for to stir men to deuocion
Then schewe I forth my longe cristall stones
Y cramed full of cloutes and of bones ¶þ
Relikes þei bene as men wenen echon
Than haf I in laton a schulder bone
Whiche þat was an holy Iwes schepe
Goode men say I take at my wordes goode kepe
Ȝiff þat þis bone be wasshen in a well
Ȝiff cowe or kalfe schepe or oxe swell
That eny worme hath eten or stonge
A boute þe herte or els þe longe
And it is hoole onon and forthermor
Of pokkes and of skabbe and of eny sor
Shall eủer/rey schepe ben hole þat of þis well
Drynketh a drauȝht taketh hede what I tell
Ȝiff þat þe goodman þat þe bestys oweth
Woll eủer/rey woke or þat þe cokke hym crowith
Fastynge drynke of þis well a draȝht
As þilke holy Iwe our eldres tauȝht
His bestis and his stor schall multiplie
And sirres also it helith Ialowsie
And þof a man be fallen in a Iolose rage
Lete maken with þis wat̉er/re his potage
And neủer/re schall he his wyffe mystruste
Thof he þe sothe of hir defaute wyste
Al had sche taken pstes tweyn or three
Her is a myteyn eke þat ȝe may see
He þat his honde will put in þis myteyn
He schall haue multiplyyng of his greyn
When he hath sowen be it whete or otes
So þat he brynge me goode penys or els grotes
And men and wōmmen oo thynge I warne ȝowe
Ȝiff eny wiȝht be in þis chirche nowe
That hath done synne horrible þat he
Dar not for schame of it shryffen be
Or eny woman be sche ȝonge or olde
That hath y made hir husbonde cokewollde
Suche folke schull haue no power ne no grace
To offer to my relikes in þis plase
And who so fyndeth hym oute of suche blame
Thei woll come up and offer in goddis name
And I assoile hem by þe Auctorite
Suche as my bull was graunted to me
Be þis gawde haf I wonen eủer/rey ȝere
An hundreth marke sethens I was ꝑper/pardoner
I stonde like a clerke in my pulpite
And schewe lewde peples synne I sette
I preche so as I haf lerede be fore
And tell an hundreth Iapes mor ¶þ
Then peyn I me to strecche forth þe nekke
And este and weste opon þe peple I bekke
As doith a doufe sittynge opon a berne
Myn hondes and my tonge gone full ȝerne
That it is ioie to se my besynesse
Of auarice and suche Cursednes
Is all my prechynge for to make hem free
To ȝeue her penys and namely to mee
Formyn entente is noȝt but for to wynne
And no thynge for correccioıı̄un of synne
I rekke neủer/re when þat þei bene beriede
Þof þat her soules gone of blakburiede
For certꝭes mony a pdicacioıı̄un
Comyth oftyme of euyll entencioıı̄un
Som for plesance of folke and for flaterye
To bene a vaunced by ypocrisie
And som for veyn glorie and for hate
For when I dar not other waies debate
Then will I stynge hem with my tonge smerte
In prechynge so þat he schall not sterte
To bene diffamede falsly so þat he
Þat hath trespassed to my brethern or to me
For þof I tell not his ꝓpropre name
Men schall wele knowe þat it is þe same
By som signe and other circumstaunces
Thus smyte I folke þat doith us displesaunces
Thus spute I oute my venym vnder hewe
Of holynes to semen holy and trewe
But schortly myn entente I woll deuyse
I preche of no thynge but of couetise
Ther for my teme is ȝit and eủer/re was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Thus can I preche a ȝeyn þe same vice
Whiche þat I vse and þat is auarice
But þof my selfe be gilty in þat synne
Ȝit con I make oþ̉er/re folke to wynne
From auarice and sor hem repente
But þat nys not my pⁱrincipall entente
I preche not but for couetise
Of þis mat̉er/re it aught ynogh suffise
Then tell I hem ensamples mony one
Of olde stories longe tyme agone
For lewed peple louen tales olde
Swiche thyngꝭes kon þei reporte and holde
What trowe ȝe þat whils I may preeche
And wynnen golde and siluer for to teche
That I will lyue in pouerte wilfully
Nay nay I thoucht it neủer/re trewly
For I will preche and begge in sondry londes
I will not do no labour with myn hondes
Ne maken Baskettꝭes and lyue þer by
Because I woll not lyuen ydully
I woll none of þe apostells countrefete
I will haf monye malte chese and whete
Al wer it ȝiffen of þe poreste page
Oþ of þe porest wydowe in a vilage
Al schuld hir children sterue or famyn
And I woll drynke þe licoreste of þe wyne
And haf a . Ioly wenche in eủer/rey town
But herkenith lordes in conclusioun
Ȝour likynge is þat I schall tell a tale
Nowe I haue dronken a draught of corny ale
By god I hope I schall tell ȝowe a thynge
That schall be resoun be at ȝour likynge
For þof my selfe be a full vicious man
A morall tale ȝit I ȝowe tell can
Whiche Iames wente to pche for to wynne
Nowe holdeth ȝour pees my tale I woll be gynne
IN flaundres whilom was a companye
Of ȝonge folke þat haunted folye
As hasarde ryote stewes and tavernes
Harpes ribibes lutes and gyternes
Thei dauncen and pleyen at þe dyse nyȝht and daye
And eten also oủer/re þat her myȝht may
Thurgh whiche þei don þe deuell sacrifice
With in þe deuylls temple in sundry wyse
By supfluyte abhominable
Her othes bene so grete and dampnable
That it is grisly for to her swer
Our blessed lordes body þei al to ter
Hem thought Iwys rente hym noȝht ynogh
And ilke of hem at oþ̉er/res synne lowgh
And riȝht onon com in þen tomblisters
Fetys and small and ȝonge fruturers
Syngers with harpes baudes and wafres
Suche ben verrey þe deuylls officers
To kyndly and blowe þe fuyr of leccherye
That is annexed to glotonye
The holy writte take I to wytnesse
That lecchery is in wyne and dronkenesse
Lo howe þat dronken lothe vnkyndly ¶þ
Laye by his doıı̄unghtres two vnwityngly
So dronken he was he ne wyste what he wroghth
Herodes who so hath þe stories souȝht
When he of wyne was replete at his feste
Riȝht at his own table ȝaff his heste
To sleen þe baptiste Iohn full giltlesse
Seneke saith a goode worde doutelesse
He saith he kan no difference fynde
Betwix a man þat is oute of his mynde
Ande a man þat is drōmnkelewe
But þat wodnes is fallen in a schrewe
ꝐPer/Parseuerith lenger þan doith dronkenesse
O glotonye full of Cursednes
O cause firste of our confusioun
Originall of our dampnacioun
Till criste hadde bouȝht us with his bloode agayn
Lo howe der schōmrtely for to seyn
A bouȝht was þe cursed vilenye
Corrupte was al þis worlde thurgh glotenye
Adam our fader and his wyffe also
Fro ꝑper/paradise to labour and to woo
Wer dryven for þat wise it is no drede
For whiles þat Adam fasted as I rede
He was in ꝑper/paradise and when þat he
Ete of þe fruyte defended on þe tr
Onon he was oute caste to woo and peyne
O glotonye on þe well ought us to pleyn
O wyst a man howe mony maladies
Foloweth of excesse and of glotonyes
He wolde bene þe mor mesurable
Of his diete sittynge at his table
Allas þe schorte throte þe tendr mouthe
Makith þat Este and weste North and southe
In erthe in water in eyr men to synke
To geten a gloton deynte mete and drynke
Of þis mater o poule wel can þou trete
Mete vn to wombe and wombe eke vn to mete
Shall god destroye both as poule seith
Allas a foule thynge it is be my feyth
To saye þis worde and fouler is þe dede
When men so drynketh loth of white and rede
That of his throte he maketh þe priue
Thurgh þilke cursed superfluite
Thēm apostell wepynge seith full pitously
Ther walken mony of whiche tolde haf I
I seye it nowe wepynge wyth pitous voice ¶þ
Ther bene enimys of Cristis croys
Of whiche þe ende is deth wombe is her godde
O wombe o baly o stynkyng cod
Fulfilled of donge and of corrupcioıı̄un
And eiþ̉er/re ende of þe foule is þe sesoıı̄un
Howe grete coste and labour it is to fynde
Thise cokes howe þei stampe streyn and grynde
And turnen substance in to accidente
To fulfill all þi likorous talente
Oute of þe harde bones knokke þei
Þe marye for þei caste not a waye
That may go thurgh þe golet safe and soote
Of spicery of leues barke and rote
Shall bene his sawse y made be delite
To maken hym ȝit a newe appetite
But c̉er/retes he þat haunteth suche delites
Is dede whils þat he liffeth in þo vices
A leccherous thynge is wyne and dronkenes
It is full of stryvynge and of wrecchednes
O dronken man disfigured in þi face
Foul is þi breeth foule arte þou to enbrase
And thurgh þi dronkenesse sowneth þe soune
As þof þou saidest ay sampsoıı̄un sampsoıı̄un
And ȝit god wote sampsoıı̄un dronke neủer/re no wyne
Thou falleste as it wer a dronken swyne
Thy tonge is and all þine honeste cur
For dronkenes is verreye sepultur
Of mannys wytte and his discrecioun
In whome þat drynke hath dominacioıı̄un
He can no qsell kepe it is no drede
Nowe kepe ȝowe fro þe white and fro þe reede
Namely fro þe white wyne of lepe
That is to sell in fyssh strete and in chepe
This wyne of spayn crepith sotelly
In oþ̉er/re wynes growynge faste by
Of whiche riseth suche fumosite
That when a man hath dronken ij . draghtꝭes or thr
And wenyth þat he be at home in chepe
Than is he in spayn riȝht at þe toun of lepe
Noȝt at þe Rochell ne at Burdeux town
And þen woll þei seye sampsoıı̄un sampsoıı̄un
But herkenyth lordynges I ȝowe praye
That al þe souereyn actes dar I seye
Of victories in þe olde testamente
That thurgh verray god þat is omnipotente
Wer done in abstinence and in praier ¶þ
Loketh þe bible and þer may ȝe it ler
Lokith Attila þe grete conquerour
Deied in his slepe with schame and dishonour
Bledyng at his nose in dronkenesse
A capteyn schuld liffe in sobirnesse
And oủer/re al thise avise ȝowe riȝht wele
What was qmaunded vn to Lamuele
Not samuel but lamuel say I
Redith þe bible and fyndeth it expssely
Of wyne ȝeuynge of hem þat arue Iustise
No mor of þis for it may suffise
And nowe þat I haf spoken of glotonye
Nowe woll I defende ȝowe hasardye
Hasard is verray moder of lesynges
And of disceyte cursed for swerynges
Blasfeme of Criste māmnyslawht̉er/re and waste also
Of bataill and tyme and of forthermoo
It is reproued and contrarie to honour
For to be holden a comoıı̄un hasardour
And eủer/re þe hier he is of astate
Þe mor he is holden desolate
Ȝiff þat a prince vse hasardrye
In alle gouernance and pollicye
He is as by comoıı̄un opinioıı̄un
Y holde þe lesse in reputacioıı̄un
Stilbon þat was hole a wise ambassiatour
Was sent in to corinth with full grete honour
Fro calidoyn to make hym allyaunce
And when he come þen happed þe chaunce
That all þe gretteste þat wer of þat lande
Pleyynge at þe hasarde he hem fande
For whiche as sone as þat myȝht be
He stale hym home a ȝeyn to his cuntr
And seide þ̉er/re I wolde not lese my name
I wolde not take on me so grete Diffame
For to allye ȝowe to nōmn hasardours
Sendith oþer wyser ambassiatours
For be my trouthe me wer leuer dye
Then I schuld ȝowe to hasourdours alye
For ȝe þat bene so glorious in honours
Shall not allye ȝowe with nōmn hasardours
As be my will ne as be my trete
This wise philisophr þus saide he
Loke eke þat to þe kynge demetreus
The kynge of parteus as þe kynge seith þus
Sent hym a pair of dyes of golde in skorne ¶þ
For he had vsede hasardrye þ̉er/re beforne
For whiche he helde his glorie and his renoun
For no value of reputacioun
Lordes myȝht fynde other man pleye
Honest ynogh to dryue þe daye a weye
Nowe woll I speke of othes fals and grete
A worde or twoo as oþ̉er/re bookes entrete
Grete swerynge is a thynge abhominable
And fals swerynge is muche mor reprouable
The hiegh god forbad swerynge at all
Witnes of Mathewe but in speciall
Of swerynge þe holy Ieremye
Thou schalt swer soth þine othes and not lye
And swer in doome and eke in riȝhtwysnes
But ydell swerynge is a cursednes
Beholde and se þat in þe firste table
Of hiegh godꝭes hestes honurable
Howe þat two hestes of him is þis
Take not my tale in ydelnes amys
Lo rather he forbedith suche swerynge
Then homicide or eny oþer thynge
I saye as þus be ordr it stondeth
This knowith þat his hestes vnderstondeth
Howe þat þe secounde heste of god is þat
And forþ̉er/re oủer/re I woll þe tell al platte
Þat vencheance schall not ꝑper/parte from his howse
That of his othes is so outracheous
By goddys pcious herte and his naylles
And be his blode þat is in hailles
Seuen is my chaunce and his . v . and thr
Be goddꝭes armes ȝif þou falsly pleys to me
This dagger schall thurgh þine herte goo
This fruyte comyth of þilke bones twoo
For swerynge ir̉er/re falsnes homycide
Nowe for þe luff of Criste þat for us diede
Leueth ȝour othes both grete and smale
For I schall tell ȝowe a mueillous tale
Thise riotours of whiche I tell
Longe erste or prime ronge eny bell
Wer sette in a tauerne for to drynke
And as þei satte þei harde a bell clynke
By forne a corps was caried to his graue
That one of hem gan calle to his knaue
Go bet qd he and aske redily
What cors it þat þat passeth forth by
And loke þat þou reporte his name wele ¶þ
Sir qd þis knaue it nedith neủer/re a dele
It was me tolde er ȝe come her two houres
He was ꝑper/parde an olde felowe of ȝoures
Al sodenly was he slayn to nyȝhte
For dronken as he sat opon his benche up riȝht
Ther come a pryue theefe men clepen deeth
That in his contree all þe peple sleeth
And with his sper he smote his herte a twoo
And wente his waye with outen wordes moo
He Hath a thousande slayne þis pestilence
And maist̉er/re er ȝe come in his presence
Me thynketh þat it wer necessarie
For to be war of swiche an aduersarie
Beeth redy for to mete hym eủer/remore
Thus tauȝht me my dame I saye no mor
Be seynt Marie seide þis tauerner
The childe saith sothe for he hath slayn to ȝer
Hennes ouer a Mile with in a grete vilage
Both manne and woman childe and page
I trowe his habitacioıı̄un be þer
To bene avised grete wysdom it wer
Er þat he did a man dishonoure
Ȝa goddis armes qd þis ryatour
Is it suche ꝑper/parill with hym for to mete
I schall hym sechyn be stye and be strete
I make a vowe be goddis digne bones
Herkeneth felowes we thr bene allones
Let iche of us holde up his honde to other
And eche of us become oþer brother
And we will slee þis fals traitoıı̄unr deth
He schall be slayn he þat so mony sleeth
Be goddis dignite er þat it be nyȝht
To gider han þise thr her hertꝭes pliȝht
To lyff and to dye ilke on of hem with other
As þogh he wer his own sworne brother
And up þei sterten and dronken in þis rage
And forth þei gone towarde þat vilage
Of whiche þe taủer/rener hath spoken be forne
And mony a grisly othe þen haf þei sworne
And Cristꝭes blessed body þei to rente
That deeth schall be dede if þᵗat we may hym hente
When þei had gone not fully a myle
Riȝht as þei wolde haff tryned oủer/re a stile
An old and a por man with hem mette
This olde man ful mekely hem grette
And saide þus Nowe lordes god ȝowe see ¶þ
The proudest of þise riatours thr
Answerd a ȝeyn what cherle with harde grace
Why erte þou all forwrapped saue þi face
Why liffest þou so longe in so grete age
This olde man gan loke in his visage
And saide þus for I con not fynde
A man þof I walked in to ynde
Neither in Cite ner in vilage
That will chaungen his ȝouthe for myn age
And þer for mot I haf myne age still
Als longe tyme as it is goddis will
Ne deeth allas ne will not haf my liffe
Thus walke I like a resteles caytiffe
And on þe grounde whiche is my moder gate
I knokke with my staffe both arly and late
And seye leue moder lat me Inne
Loo howe I vanyssh flessh blode and skynne
Allas when schull my bones bene at reste
Moder with ȝowe wold I chaunge my cheste
That in my Chambr longe tyme hath be
Ȝa for an hier cloute to wrappe me
But ȝit to me sche will not do þat grace
For whiche ful welked is my face
But sirres to ȝowe it is no curtesye
To speken vn til an old man vilenye
But he trespased in worde or els in dede
In holy writ ȝe may ȝour selfe wele rede
A ȝenst an olde man hore opon his hede
Ȝe schuld arise þ̉er/re for I ȝiff ȝowe rede
Ne doith vn to an old man harme as nowe
No mor þan ȝe wold a man did ȝowe
In age ȝif þat ȝe so longe abide
And god be with ȝowe whedir ȝe gon or ride
I mote gon þider as I haf to goo
Nay olde cherle by god þou schalt not soo
Saide þise other hasadours onon
Thou partest not so liȝhtly be seynt Iohn
Thou spake riȝht nowe of þilke traitour dethe
That in þis contre all our frendes sleeth
Haf her my trouthe as þou arte his aspie
Tell wher he is or ells þou schalt dye
By god and by þe holy sacremente
For sothly þou arte of his assente
To sleen us ȝonge folke þou fals thefe
Nowe sirres ȝiff it be to ȝowe so leefe
To finde deth turne up þis croked way ¶þ
For in þat grove I lefte hym be my feye
Vnder a tr and þer he woll abide
Ne for ȝour boste he nyll hym no thynge hyde
Se ȝe þat oke riȝht þer ȝe schull hym fynde
God saue ȝowe þat boȝht a ȝeyn man kynde
And ȝowe amend þus saide þis olde man
And eủer/reiche of þise ryatours ranne
Til þei come to þe tr and þer þei fonde
Floreyns of golde fyne y coyned rounde
Wel nygh a seuen busshells as hem thouȝht
No leng þan aft̉er/re deth þei souȝht
But eche of hem so gladde was of þat syȝhte
For þat þe floreyns so fair warne and briȝht
That doun þei sette hem by þe pcious horde
The worste of hem he spake þe firste worde
Brethern qd he take hede what þat I saye
My witte is grete þough I bourde and pleye
This tresour hath fortune to us ȝeuen
In mirthe and Iolite our lyffe to lyffen
And liȝhtly so as it comith so woll we spende
Eye pcious goddes herte who wende
To day þat we schuld haf so fair a grace
But myȝht þis golde be caried fro þis place
Home vn to myn house or ells to ȝoures
For wele I wote þat all þis golde is oures
Then wer we in hiegh felicite
But trewly be day it may not be
Men wolde seyn þat we weren thefis stronge
And for our own tresour done us honge
As wisely and als sleighly as it myȝht
This tresour moste ben y caried be nyȝht
Wherfor I rede lete loke amonge us all
To drawe and lete see wher þe cutte woll fall
He þat hath þe cutte with herte blithe
Shall renne to þe town and þat full swythe
To brynge us brede and drenke full priuely
And two of us schull kepen full sotilly
This tresour wele and if he will not tarie
When it is nyȝht we woll þis tresour carie
Be one assente wher as us liketh beste
The tone of hem broȝht gresse in his feste
And bad hem drawe and loke on whome it wold fall
And it fell on þe ȝongeste of hem all
And forth to warde þe town he wente onon
And also sone as he was gone
The tone of hem spake onto þe toþer ¶þ
Thou woteste wele þou arte myn own sworen broþ̉er/re
Thy profete woll I tell to þe onon
Thow wotest wele þat our felowe is gone
And her is gold and þat riȝht grete plentee
That it schall deꝑper/parted be among us thr
But natheles if I can schape it so
That it deꝑper/parted wer a monge us twoo
Hadde I not done a frendes turne to þe
The toþ̉er/re answered I not howe þat myȝht be
I wold wele þat þe golde wer oures twoo
What schuld we do þat it myȝht be soo
Shall it be conseill saide þe firste schrewe
And I schall þe tellen in wordes fewe
What we schull done and brynge it aboute
I graunte qd þe toþ̉er/re with outen eny doute
That be my trouthe I will þe not bewreien
Nowe ꝙquod þe firste þou wotest wele we ben tweyen
And two of us schulln strenger be þan one
Loke when he is sette and þat onon
Arise as þof þou woldeste with hym pleye
And I schall ryuen hym thurgh þe sides tweye
Whils þat þou stroglest with hym as game
And with þi dager loke þou do þe same
And þan schall all þis gold deꝑper/partide be
My der frende betwix þe and me
Than may we bothe our lustes fulfille
And pleye at þe dice riȝht at owr own will
And þus acorded ben þise schrewes tweye
To slee þe thridde as ȝe herde me seye
This ȝongest whiche þat wente to þe toun
Full ofte in his herte it rolled up and doun
The beaute of þise florens fair and briȝht
O lorde qd he ȝiff it so wer I myȝht
Haue al þis tresour to my selfe allone
Ther is no man þat liffeth vndir trone
Of gold þat schuld bene als mery as I
And at þe laste þe fende our enmye
Put in his thouȝht þat he schuld bye poyson
With whiche he myȝht sleen his felowes tweyn
For why þe fende fonde hym in suche lyffynge
That he had power hym to sorowe brynge
For þis was outrely his entente
To sleen hem bothe and neủer/re to repente
And forth he goith no lenger wolde he tarie
In to þe toune vn to apotecarie
And preied hym þat he hym wolde sell ¶þ
Som poisen þat he myȝht his rattes kyll
And eke þer was a polcat in his hawe
That as he saide his chapons had he slawe
And seide he wolde wreke hym ȝif he myȝht
Of vermyn þat destroied hym be nyȝht
The potykarie answered þou schalte haue
A thynge þat as god my soule saue
In all þis worlde þernys no creatur
That etyth or drynketh of þis confectur
Noȝht but þe mounteyns of a corne of whete
That he ne schall his liffe onon for lete
Ȝa . sterue he schall and þat in lasse while
Than þou wolte gone a pace not but a myle
This poyson þat is so herde and violente
This cursed man hath in his honde it hente
This poisen in a box and sethens he ranne
In to þe nexte strete vn to a man
And borowed hym large botells thr
To his felowes onon repaireth he
What nedith it to sermon þer of mor
For riȝht as þei had caste his dethe befor
Riȝht so þei hauen hym slayn and þat onon
Nowe lat us sitte and drynke and make us merye
And aft̉er/rewarde we wolen his bodye berye
And aft̉er/re þat it happed hem ꝑper/par cas
To taken a botell wher in þe poisen was
And dranke and ȝaf his felowe drynke also
Thurgh whiche onon þei sterueden both twoo
But certes I suppose þat avisen
Wrote neủer/re in no canon ne in no fen
Mo wonder sorowes of enpoysenynge
Then hadde þise wrecches two at her endynge
Thus ended bene þise homicides two
And eke þis fals enpoysoner also
O cursed synne full of all cursednes
O traitours homicides o wykkednes
O glotonye luxurie and hasardrye
Thou blasfemour of Criste with vilanye
And othes grete of vsage and of pryde
Allas man kynde howe may it be tide
That to þi creatour whiche þat þe wroȝht
And with his pcious blode þe bouȝht
Thou art so fals and so vnkynde allas
Nowe goode men godde forȝiff ȝowe ȝo trespasse
And kepe ȝowe fro þe synne of auarice ¶þ
Myn holy ꝑper/pardoun may ȝowe alle waryssh
So þat ȝe offer nobles or sterlynges
Or ells silủer/re spones broches or rynges
Bowith ȝowr hede vndir þis bull
Cometh up ȝe wiffes offereth þat ȝe woll
Ȝour names I entr her in my Roll onon
In to þe blisse of heuen schull ȝe al gone
I ȝowe assoile be myn hie power
Ȝe þat wollen as clene and eke als cler
As ȝe weren borne and lo sirres þus I pche
And ihu Criste þat is our soules leche
So graunte ȝowe his ꝑper/pardoun to resseyue
For þat is beste I will ȝowe not desseyue
Bot sirres o worde forgat I in my tale
I haf relikes and ꝑper/pardoıı̄un in my male
Als fair as eny man in Englonde
Whiche wer ȝiffe to me by þe popes honde
Ȝiff eny of ȝowe will of deuocion
Offeren and han myn absolucion
Comyth forth onon and knelith her a doun
That ȝe may haf ꝑper/parte of my ꝑper/pardoun
Or ells takith ꝑper/pardon as ȝe wende
Al newe and fressh at eủer/rey townes ende
So þat ȝe offren alwey newe and newe
Nobles and penys whiche þat bene goode and trewe
It is an honour to eủer/reichon þat bene her
That ȝe may haf a suffisaunt ꝑper/pardoner
To assoile ȝowe in cuntr as ȝe ride
For auentures whiche þat may betide
For ꝑper/parauentur þer may fall one or twoo
Doun of his hors and breke his nekke a twoo
Loke whiche a surtee it is to ȝowe all
That I am in ȝour felyschipe yfall
That may assoile ȝowe both mor and lesse
When þat þe soule schall fro þe body passe
I rede þat hour schall begynne
For he is moste en volupte of synne
Cometh forth sir ooste and offreth firste onon
And þou schalt kysse þe relikes eủer/reychon
Ȝa for a grote vnbokell onone þi porse
Nay nay qd he þan haf I cristes curse
Let be ꝙquod he it schall not be so theche
Thou woldest maken me kyssen þine olde breche
And swer it wer þe relike of a seynte
Þof it wer with þi fondement depeynte
But by þe crosse whiche seynt eleyn fonde
I wolde I hadde þi coylion in myn honde In stede of relikes or seynt warye¶þ

div.l: In stede of Relikes or saynt warie
Lete cutte hem of and I woll hem helpe to carie
Thei schuld be schryned in an hogges turde
This ꝑper/pardoner answered not a worde
So wrothe he was he wolde no word saye
Nowe qd our ooste I woll no lenger playe
With þe ne with none other angry manne
But riȝht onon þe worthy knyȝht beganne
Whan þat he sawgh þat al þe peple lough
No mor of þis for it is riȝht ynogh
Sir ꝑper/pardoner be mery and gladde of cher
And ȝe sir ooste þat bene to me so der
I pray ȝowe þat ȝe kysse þe ꝑper/pardoner
And ꝑper/pardoner I pray ȝowe drawe ȝowe ner
And as we dide let us lagh and pleye
And onon þei kissed and riden forth þer weye
¶ Here endeth þe ꝑper/pardoners tale .
¶ Here begynneth the prologe of sir thopace ;
Whan saide was þis tale eủer/rey man
As sober was þat wonder was to see
Til þat our hoste a Iape beganne
And þan at erste he loked opon me
And saide þus what man arte þou qd he
Thowe lokest as þou woldeste fynde an hare
For eủer/re opon þe grounde I see þe star
¶ Approche þan and loke meryly
Nowe war ȝowe sirres and lat ȝour men haf place
He in þe waste is schape als wele as I
This war a popet in armes to embrase
For eny woman small and fair of face
He semyth elvys by his countenᵃnce
For vn to no wyȝht doith he daliaunce
¶ Say nowe somwhat sethens oþ̉er/re folke han seide
Tell us a tale of myrthe and þat onon
Oost qd I ne be not euyll apaiede
For oþer tale certes can I none
But of a Ryme I lerned longe a gone
Ȝa þat is goode ꝙquod he schull we here
Som deynte thynge me semyth be his cher
Here begynneth þe tale of Chaucer be sir thopas
Listeneth lordynges in goode entente
And I woll tell varraimente
Of miracle and of solace
Of a knyȝht was fair and gente
In bataille and in tornamente
His name was sir thopas
Y borne he was in ferr cuntr
In flaundres alle be ȝonde þe see
At poperynge in þe prelace
His fader was a man full free
And lorde he was of þat cuntr
As it was goddes grace
Sir thopas was a doughty swayn
White was his face as payndemayn
His lippes rede as roose
His rodde y like skarlet in grayn
And I ȝowe tell in goode certeyn
He had a semely nose
His her his berde was like saffron
That to his girdell kauȝt a doun
His schone of Cordwayne
Of brugges wer his hosen broun
His robe was of Ciclatoun
That cost mony a Reyn
He couthe hunte at þe wilde der
And ride on hawkynge for þe ryuer
With grey goshawke on honde
Therto he was a goode Archer
To wrastlynge was þ̉er/re none his per
Ther eny man schulde stonde
Full mony a maide bryȝht in lour
Thei morne for him ꝑper/paramour
Whan þei wer better to slepe
But he was chaste and no lecchour
And swete as is þe bremble flour
That bereth þe rede heppe
And so byfell opon a daye
For sothe as I ȝowe tell may
Sir thopas wold oute ride
He worthe up on his stede greye
And in his honde a launcegay
A longe swerde be his side
He priketh thurgh a fair foreste
Ther in is mōmny a wilde beste
Ia both bukke and hare
And as he pryketh north and eeste
I tell ȝowe hym had al meste
Betidde a sory care
Ther springen herbes grete and smale
Þe likorice and þe setuale
And mony a clowe gilofr
And notemuges to putte in ale
Wheder it be moiste or stale
Or for to laye in coffr
Þe briddes syngen it is none nay
The sperhauke and þe popenIay
That Ioye it was for to here
The throstell cok made eke his laye
The wode douse opon þe spraye
She songe full loude and cler
Sir thopas fell in loue longynge
And when he harde þe throstell synge
He prikkes as he wer woode
His fair stede in his prikkynge
So swette þat men miȝht hym wrynge
His sides wer al blode
Sir thopas eke so wery was
For prikkynge on þe softe gras
So fers was his corage
That doune he laide hym in þat place
To maken his stede som solas
For he was so sauage
O seynt Marie benedicite
What ayleth þis loue at me
To bynde me so sor
Me dremed al þis nyȝht ꝑper/parde
An elfe quene schall my leman be
And slepe vndyr my gore
And an elue quene woll I loue I wys
For in þis worlde no wōmman is
Worthy to be my make
in toun
Al other women I forsake
And to an elf quene I me take
By dale and eke be doune
In to his sadell he come onone
And prikketh oủer/re stile and stone
An elfe quene for to aspie
Till he so longe hath riden and gone
That he fonde in a pryuee woon
Þe cuntr of farye
¶ So wilde .
For in þat cuntr nas þ̉er/re none
Neþ̉er/re wyffe ne childe
Till hym þ̉er/re come a Ioly geaunt
His name was cleped ʆser/sir olifaunt
A ꝑper/parlious man of dede
He seide childe be termagaunte
But if þou prik oute of myn haunte
A noon I slee þi stede
¶ With mace
Here is þe quene of fairye
With harpe and pipe and symphonye
Dwellynge in þis place
The childe saide so mot I the
To morowe schall I meten þe
When I haf myn Armour
And ȝit I hope ꝑper/parma faye
That þou schalt with þis launcelay
Abyen it full sore
¶ Thurgh þi mawe
Shall I perce ȝif I may
Or it be fully prime of þe daye
For her þou schalt be slawe
Sir thopas drewgh o bak ful faste
This geaunt at hym stones caste
Out of a fell staff slynge
But fair escapeth childe thopas
And al it was thurgh goddis grace
And thurgh his faire berynge
Ȝit listneth lordes to my tale
Murier þan þe nyȝhtyngale
For nowe I woll ȝowe rowne
Howe ʆser/sir thopas with sides smale
Prikkyng ouer doune and dale
Is come a ȝeyn to town
His mery men 9mandede he
To make hym both game and glee /
For nedes moste he fyȝht
With one geaut with hedes thr /
For ꝑper/paramour and Iolite
Of one þat schone full bryȝht
Do come he seide my mynstralls
And gestours for to tell us tales
Anon in myn armynge
Of romauns þat bene reals
Of s and of Cardinales
And eke of loue likynge
They fette hym firste þe swete wyne
And likoresse and eke comyn
With sugr þat is cree
He did nexte his white leer
Of clooth of lake fyne and cler
A breche and eke a scherte
And nexte his scherte an aketon
And oủer/re þat an haburione
For percynge of an herte
And oủer/re þat a fyne hauberke
Was al y wroȝht of Iwes werke
Full stronge it was of plate
And oủer/re þat his cote armour
Als white as is þe lily flour
In whiche he will debate
His schelde was of golde so rede
And þ̉er/re in was a bores hede
A charbocle be his side
And þer he swor on ale and brede
Howe þat þe geaunte schall be dede
Betide what betyde
His Iaumbeure wer of quirbole
His swerde scheth of yuery
